Authors: Duc Khai, D.K.; Du, C.V.; Pham, H.L.
Author full names: Duc Khai, Khai Duc (56650569500); Du, Cam Vinh (58535447100); Pham, Hoai Luan (57207990013)
Title: QuantLaneNet: A 640-FPS and 34-GOPS/W FPGA-Based CNN Accelerator for Lane Detection
Affiliations: Department of Computer Engineering, VNUHCM - University of Information Technology, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Graduate School of Information Science, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Duc Khai, Khai Duc, Department of Computer Engineering, VNUHCM - University of Information Technology, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Du, Cam Vinh, Department of Computer Engineering, VNUHCM - University of Information Technology, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Pham, Hoai Luan, Graduate School of Information Science, Nara Institute of Science and Technology, Ikoma, Japan
Abstract: Lane detection is one of the most fundamental problems in the rapidly developing field of autonomous vehicles. With the dramatic growth of deep learning in recent years, many models have achieved a high accuracy for this task. However, most existing deep-learning methods for lane detection face two main problems. First, most early studies usually follow a segmentation approach, which requires much post-processing to extract the necessary geometric information about the lane lines. Second, many models fail to reach real-time speed due to the high complexity of model architecture. To offer a solution to these problems, this paper proposes a lightweight convolutional neural network that requires only two small arrays for minimum post-processing, instead of segmentation maps for the task of lane detection. This proposed network utilizes a simple lane representation format for its output. The proposed model can achieve 93.53% accuracy on the TuSimple dataset. A hardware accelerator is proposed and implemented on the Virtex-7 VC707 FPGA platform to optimize processing time and power consumption. Several techniques, including data quantization to reduce data width down to 8-bit, exploring various loop-unrolling strategies for different convolution layers, and pipelined computation across layers, are optimized in the proposed hardware accelerator architecture. This implementation can process at 640 FPS while consuming only 10.309 W, equating to a computation throughput of 345.6 GOPS and energy efficiency of 33.52 GOPS/W. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: convolutional neural network; FPGA; hardware architecture; lane detection; QuantLaneNet

Title: B-fields and Dust in Interstellar Filaments Using Dust Polarization (BALLAD-POL). I. The Massive Filament G11.11-0.12 Observed by SOFIA/HAWC+
Affiliations: Department of Astrophysics, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Korea Astronomy and Space Science Institute, Daejeon, South Korea; University of Science and Technology (UST), Daejeon, South Korea; Max Planck Institute for Radio Astronomy, Bonn, Germany; Astronomy and Informatics, Uniwersytet Mikołaja Kopernika w Toruniu, Torun, Poland; Center for Data-Driven Discovery, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; ICISE, Quy Nhon, Viet Nam; Centre de Recherche Astrophysique de Lyon, Saint-Genis-Laval, France
Authors with affiliations: Ngoc, Nguyen Bich, Department of Astrophysics, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Diep, Pham Ngoc, Department of Astrophysics, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hoang, Thiem C., Korea Astronomy and Space Science Institute, Daejeon, South Korea, University of Science and Technology (UST), Daejeon, South Korea; Tram, Le Ngoc, Max Planck Institute for Radio Astronomy, Bonn, Germany; Giang, Nguyenchau, Korea Astronomy and Space Science Institute, Daejeon, South Korea, University of Science and Technology (UST), Daejeon, South Korea; Le, Ngan M., Astronomy and Informatics, Uniwersytet Mikołaja Kopernika w Toruniu, Torun, Poland; Hoang, Thuong Duc, Center for Data-Driven Discovery, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Phuong, Nguyen Thi, Department of Astrophysics, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Korea Astronomy and Space Science Institute, Daejeon, South Korea; Khang, Nguyenminh, ICISE, Quy Nhon, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Dieu Duc, Centre de Recherche Astrophysique de Lyon, Saint-Genis-Laval, France; Truong, Bao, Korea Astronomy and Space Science Institute, Daejeon, South Korea, University of Science and Technology (UST), Daejeon, South Korea
Abstract: We report the first measurement of polarized thermal dust emission toward the entire infrared dark cloud G11.11−0.12 taken by the polarimeter SOFIA/HAWC+ at 214 μm. The obtained magnetic fields (B-fields) from the polarized emission of the early-stage and massive filament tend to be perpendicular to its spine. We produce a map of B-field strengths for the center region of the filament. The strengths vary in the range of 100-600 μG and are strongest along the filament's spine. The central region is sub-Alfvénic and mostly subcritical, meaning that B-fields dominate over turbulence and are strong enough to resist gravitational collapse. The alignment and properties of dust grains in the filament are studied using radiative torque (RAT) theory. We find the decrease of polarization degree P with emission intensity I, i.e., depolarization effect, of the form P ∝ I −α  with α ∼ 0.8-0.9, implying a significant loss of grain alignment in the filament's spine. The depolarization can be explained by the decrease in RAT alignment efficiency toward the denser regions with weaker radiation field, which cannot be explained by B-field tangling. We study the effect of the enhanced magnetic relaxation by embedded iron inclusions on RAT alignment and find that the high polarization fraction P ∼ 20%-30% in the outer layer of the filament is potential evidence for the magnetically enhanced RAT alignment mechanism. This is the first time this effect is evaluated in a filament. Based on the polarization fraction and RAT alignment theory, we also find evidence for grain growth in the filament. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Diblock copolymers poly(3-hexylthiophene)-block-poly(2-(dimethylamino)ethyl methacrylate-random-1-pyrenylmethyl methacrylate), controlled synthesis and optical properties
Affiliations: National Key Laboratory of Polymer and Composite Materials, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Faculty of Materials Technology, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Institute of Applied Materials Science, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Chemistry, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Department of Material and Life Chemistry, Kanagawa University, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Le Nguyen, Thao Phuong, National Key Laboratory of Polymer and Composite Materials, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Bui, Thao Thanh, National Key Laboratory of Polymer and Composite Materials, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Cam Hong Thi, National Key Laboratory of Polymer and Composite Materials, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Le, Duongthanh, National Key Laboratory of Polymer and Composite Materials, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Tam Huu, National Key Laboratory of Polymer and Composite Materials, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Department of Material and Life Chemistry, Kanagawa University, Yokohama, Japan; Nguyen, Le Thu Thi, Faculty of Materials Technology, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Quoc Thiet, Institute of Applied Materials Science, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hoang, Maiha, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Chemistry, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Yokozawa, Tsutomu, Department of Material and Life Chemistry, Kanagawa University, Yokohama, Japan; Nguyen, Ha Tran T., National Key Laboratory of Polymer and Composite Materials, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: In this research, diblock copolymers based on the rod segment of regioregular poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT) and a coil segment of poly(2-(dimethylamino)ethyl methacrylate-random-1-pyrenylmethyl methacrylate) (P(DMAEMA-r-PyMA)) was synthesized successfully by Grignard metathesis (GRIM) method and atom transfer radical polymerization reaction (ATRP). The obtained copolymer was well-defined with an average molecular weight of 11300 g/mol and low polydispersity below 1.5. The polymer structure was determined via gel permeation chromatography (GPC), Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy and proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectroscopies. In addition, the optical and thermal properties of polymers were characterized via ultraviolet–visible (UV–Vis), differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) spectroscopy and fluorescence spectroscopy. Interestingly, P3HT-b-P(DMAEMA-r-PyMA) was examined as a possible chemosensor for trace detection of the trinitrotoluene (TNT) explosive. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Chinh, Nguyen Ngoc (57221388828); Ha, Nguyen Thi Hoang (58179651700); Doanh, Pham Ngoc (16027633300); Eiras, Jorge Costa (7005430268); Whipps, Christopher M. (6603055397); Shirakashi, Sho (8646459200)
Title: Synopsis of myxosporean species (Cnidaria: Myxozoa) parasitizing fishes from Vietnam
Affiliations: Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Ecology and Biological Resources, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Ecology and Biological Resources, Hanoi, Viet Nam; CIIMAR - Interdisciplinary Centre of Marine and Environmental Research, Matosinhos, Portugal; Universidade do Porto, Porto, Portugal; Department of Environmental Biology, SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry, Syracuse, United States; Aquaculture Research Institute, Kindai University, Higashiosaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Chinh, Nguyen Ngoc, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Ecology and Biological Resources, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ha, Nguyen Thi Hoang, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Ecology and Biological Resources, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Doanh, Pham Ngoc, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Ecology and Biological Resources, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Eiras, Jorge Costa, CIIMAR - Interdisciplinary Centre of Marine and Environmental Research, Matosinhos, Portugal, Universidade do Porto, Porto, Portugal; Whipps, Christopher M., Department of Environmental Biology, SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry, Syracuse, United States; Shirakashi, Sho, Aquaculture Research Institute, Kindai University, Higashiosaka, Japan
Abstract: This paper provides an updated checklist of species-level identified myxosporeans from marine and freshwater fishes in Vietnam. The list includes 51 nominal species (38 marine and 13 freshwater) belonging to 9 genera: Myxobolus Bütschli, 1882 (26 species); Kudoa Meglitsch, 1947 (6 species); Henneguya Thélohan, 1892 (6 species); Thelohanellus Kudo, 1933 (5 species); Unicapsula Davis, 1924 (2 species); Ceratomyxa Thélohan, 1892 (2 species), Zschokkella Auerbach, 1909 (2 species); Auerbachia Meglitsch, 1960 (1 species), and Meglitschia Kovaleva, 1988 (1 species). For each parasite species, information on myxospore morphology, line drawings, fish hosts, infection sites, and collection locality in Vietnam are reported. Where available, we also provide GenBank accession numbers for nucleotide sequence data. In addition, taxonomic status of several species was discussed and Myxobolus eszterbaueri nom. nov. is proposed as a junior homonym for Myxobolus hakyi Baska, Voronin, Eszterbauer, Müller, Marton & Molnár 2009, which is preoccupied. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Diversity; Fish parasites; Myxosporeans

Author full names: Ngoc Nguyen, Phuong (56177450300); Tran, Trang Thanh (57825694600); Thi Nguyen, Quynh Anh (57226366601); Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki (57208764411); Prabhakar Vattikuti, Surya Veerendra (57542619100); Le, Long V. (58513875500); Bui, Viet Quoc (55602465800); Nguyen, Tuan Manh (57916001100); Dang Nam, Nguyen (57216456831)
Title: Constructing a rhenium complex supported on g-C3N4 for efficient visible-light-driven photoreduction of CO2 to CO via a novel Z-scheme heterojunction
Affiliations: Institute of Applied Materials Science, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Graduate University of Science and Technology, Cau Giay, Viet Nam; Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Institute of Science, Suranaree University of Technology, Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand; Physics and Nanotechnoloy, SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur, India; School of Mechanical Engineering, Yeungnam University, Gyeongsan, South Korea; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; National Institute of Applied Mechanics and Informatics, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Future Materials & Devices Lab., Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Faculty of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Ngoc Nguyen, Phuong, Institute of Applied Materials Science, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Graduate University of Science and Technology, Cau Giay, Viet Nam; Tran, Trang Thanh, Institute of Applied Materials Science, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thi Nguyen, Quynh Anh, Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan, Institute of Science, Suranaree University of Technology, Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand, Physics and Nanotechnoloy, SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur, India; Prabhakar Vattikuti, Surya Veerendra, School of Mechanical Engineering, Yeungnam University, Gyeongsan, South Korea; Le, Long V., Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Bui, Viet Quoc, Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Tuan Manh, Graduate University of Science and Technology, Cau Giay, Viet Nam, National Institute of Applied Mechanics and Informatics, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dang Nam, Nguyen, Future Materials & Devices Lab., Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam, Faculty of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Abstract: Visible-light-driven photocatalytic CO<inf>2</inf> reduction is a promising approach to addressing the problem of global warming and the energy crisis. A Z-scheme photocatalyst comprising a Re(i) complex and a polymeric semiconductor (bulk graphitic carbon nitride (g-C<inf>3</inf>N<inf>4</inf>)) converted CO<inf>2</inf> to CO even under the irradiation of low-intensity visible light. The electronic interaction between Re(i) and g-C<inf>3</inf>N<inf>4</inf> units and the injection of electrons from g-C<inf>3</inf>N<inf>4</inf> to the Re(i) complex improved the photocatalytic efficiency. The lower recombination of electron-hole pairs and the prolonged emission decay (the average emission lifetime τ = 5.8 ms) contributed to the increased overall efficiency of the hybrid system. The maximum turnover number (TON) of CO formation reached 28.56 after 240 min with a high CO selectivity (99.8%). Compared to the homogeneous photocatalyst Re(i), the TON of CO formation was increased by 5.6 times and CO selectivity was higher. Density Functional Theory (DFT) was employed to investigate the impact of the substrate-supported Re complex (Re(bpy-COOH)/g-C<inf>3</inf>N<inf>4</inf>) on the CO<inf>2</inf> Reduction Reaction (CO2RR) activity. The results indicate that Re(bpy-COOH)/g-C<inf>3</inf>N<inf>4</inf> presents a lower energy barrier for *CO<inf>2</inf> to *COOH conversion, promoting *COOH formation more effectively than pure g-C<inf>3</inf>N<inf>4</inf>. Moreover, the energy barrier for *CO desorption is lower in Re(bpy-COOH)/g-C<inf>3</inf>N<inf>4</inf> than in Re(bpy-COOH), suggesting a reduction in the strong binding of adsorbed CO intermediates, highlighting the intermediate ensemble effect at the active site. The improved CO2RR activity in Re(bpy-COOH)/g-C<inf>3</inf>N<inf>4</inf> can be attributed to the balance between the enhancement of reaction activity and the binding energy of intermediates at the active site. The study of photocatalytic CO<inf>2</inf> reduction (PCO2R) under low-intensity-visible-light irradiation and DFT investigation has reveal an insight into the CO2RR activity for CO<inf>2</inf> reduction under various irradiation conditions. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Binding energy; Carbon nitride; Density functional theory; Energy barriers; Energy policy; Global warming; Heterojunctions; Hybrid systems; Irradiation; Photocatalytic activity; Reaction intermediates; Rhenium compounds; CO 2 reduction; CO formation; CO selectivity; Low-intensity; Photo-catalytic; Re complex; Reaction activity; Reduction reaction; Turnover number; Visible-light-driven; Carbon dioxide

Authors: Nang, L.N.; Phat, L.V.; Tien, P.M.; Hieu, P.T.; Kawaguchi, K.; Minh, P.
Author full names: Nang, Lengoc (59596208800); Phat, Lam Vinh (57913918000); Tien, Pham Minh (57913282800); Hieu, Pham Trung (58294744100); Kawaguchi, Kenta (57204628400); Minh, Phạm (57192084611)
Title: GEM-QUALITY AUGITE FROM DONG NAI, VIETNAM
Affiliations: Faculty of Geology, University of Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; the University of Science, National University Faculty of Geology, Viet Nam; Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nang, Lengoc, Faculty of Geology, University of Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Phat, Lam Vinh, Faculty of Geology, University of Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tien, Pham Minh, the University of Science, National University Faculty of Geology, Viet Nam; Hieu, Pham Trung, the University of Science, National University Faculty of Geology, Viet Nam; Kawaguchi, Kenta, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan; Minh, Phạm, Kyushu University, Fukuoka, Japan
Abstract: Augite from Dong Nai Province in Vietnam occurs as xenocrysts hosted by Cenozoic basalt and its regolith. Found as irregularly shaped crystals a few millimeters to centimeters in size, these augites exhibit two dominant colors: brown and green. They are very dark in tone, making them appear almost black in reflected light and are translucent to transparent, with vitreous luster. Most of the samples’ gemological properties are similar except for refractive index and birefringence values, which are both higher in green augite. The brown and green augite samples show differences in Raman peak positions. The chemical composition as determined by electron probe microanalysis suggests that Dong Nai augite should be classified as magnesium-rich augite. This material is promising for jewelry use, as gem-quality material is readily found over a large area. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Patterns of Breastfeeding Practices among Mothers in Two Urban Cities in Vietnam
Affiliations: School of Medicine and Pharmacy, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; American University of the Caribbean School of Medicine, Sint Maarten, Netherlands; International Ph.D. Program in Medicine, College of Medicine, Taipei, Taiwan; Research Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine, Taipei Medical University, Taipei, Taiwan; Faculty of Medicine, Università degli Studi di Milano, Milan, Italy; School of Tropical Medicine and Global Health, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Giang, Hoang Thi Nam, School of Medicine and Pharmacy, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Duy, Do Thi Thuy, School of Medicine and Pharmacy, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Khowaja, Faisal, American University of the Caribbean School of Medicine, Sint Maarten, Netherlands; Minh, Le Huu Nhat, International Ph.D. Program in Medicine, College of Medicine, Taipei, Taiwan, Research Center for Artificial Intelligence in Medicine, Taipei Medical University, Taipei, Taiwan; Pham, Hoang Nhat, Faculty of Medicine, Università degli Studi di Milano, Milan, Italy; Hieu, Le Tho Minh, School of Medicine and Pharmacy, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Huy, Nguyen Tien, School of Tropical Medicine and Global Health, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan
Abstract: INTRODUCTION: Breastfeeding is associated with lower risk of child morbidity and mortality and foster overall child development. However, suboptimal breastfeeding practices have been reported in many countries. This study aims to describe patterns of breastfeeding from birth to 24 months in Vietnam and examine factors associated with the maintenance of breastfeeding at 12 months. MATERIALS AND METHODS: 573 mothers whose infants aged from 12 to 24 months in a multi-centre cross-sectional study were recruited. RESULTS: The prevalence of initiation of breastfeeding within the first hour post-partum was 52.9%, between 1 to 24 hours was 21.9%, after the 24 hours was 25.2% and none not initiated by the 7th day after birth. The prevalence of delayed initiation of breastfeeding was significantly higher in caesarean section than in vaginal births (p=0.0001). Prevalence of infants ever breastfed was 100%; exclusively breastfed at 6 months was 19.7%, continued breastfeeding at 12 months was 92.5%, and continued breastfeeding at 20-24 months was 43.5%. There were 16.4% of mothers had breastfeeding problems. Correctly describing the recommended duration of exclusive breastfeeding and not using a bottle to give expressed milk to the infants were factors associated with the higher prevalence of breastfeeding maintenance for 12 months. CONCLUSION: Early initiation of breastfeeding and exclusive breastfeeding prevalence at 6 months in our study earn rating of “good” and “fair” respectively according to World Health Organization (WHO) recommendation. Improving mothers’ knowledge of exclusive breastfeeding recommendations and educating about breast milk expression may improve the prevalence of breastfeeding maintenance at 12 months. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: 12 months; associated factors; breastfeeding; breastfeeding problem; early initiation breastfeeding

Authors: Bui, T.-A.; Ngoc-Tam, N.-T.
Author full names: Bui, Tuan Anh (45960912000); Ngoc-Tam, Bui (57212681073)
Title: Investigating the Impact of Fly-Ash Additive on Viscosity Reduction at Different Temperatures: A Comparative Analysis
Affiliations: School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Innovative Global Program, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Bui, Tuan Anh, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ngoc-Tam, Bui, Innovative Global Program, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The viscosity of lubricating oils is influenced by fly-ash additives and temperature, as they play a crucial role in regulating the viscosity of oils. Fly-ash additives are added to lubricating oils to improve oxidation resistance and prevent deposit formation, which may reduce viscosity loss at high temperatures. This study aimed to investigate the impact of fly-ash additives and temperature on the viscosity of oils B, C, and A. The experimental methodology involved comparing the viscosity of these oils with and without the addition of a 0.5% fly-ash additive. Viscosity measurements were taken at different temperatures. The results showed significant changes in viscosity after incorporating the fly-ash additive. At 25 °C, oils B, C, and A exhibited viscosity increases of 6.2%, 8.1%, and 13.8%, respectively, compared to the samples without the additive. Similarly, at 75 °C, the viscosity increments were 10.2%, 11.5%, and 22.8% for oils B, C, and A, respectively. At 85 °C, the corresponding increments were 11.1%, 16.6%, and 32.8%. These findings highlight the effectiveness of fly-ash additives in reducing the impact of temperature on oil viscosity, with oil A demonstrating the highest efficacy. By adjusting the viscosity of the oil at different temperatures, the fly-ash additives contribute to maintaining stable lubricating performance. Understanding the influence of fly-ash additives and temperature on oil viscosity is crucial for optimizing the performance of lubricants across various temperature conditions. Additionally, this knowledge assists in selecting the appropriate additive ratios for specific applications, thereby ensuring optimal lubricant performance. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: fly-ash additive; shear stress; temperature; viscosity

Title: A flexible and efficient FPGA-based random forest architecture for IoT applications
Affiliations: Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Dinh, Trung Pham, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Pham-Quoc, Cuong, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thinh, Tran Ngoc Huy, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Binh Kieu Do, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan; Kha, Pham Cong, The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan
Abstract: In recent years, machine learning algorithms have been used in many areas, from high-performance to edge computing. As one of the most attractive machine learning algorithms, random forest is widely used in many fields. However, the random forest algorithm is computational and resource intensive, especially for large datasets. Therefore, it is not widely used for IoT applications. This paper proposes a flexible and efficient FPGA-based architecture for random forest targeting edge computing platforms where resources and computing power are limited. The architecture allows the number of decision trees in the random forest to be reconfigured for a particular platform. To improve the system's performance based on this architecture, we design a pipeline decision tree processor to compute decision trees that are the main components of the random forest algorithm. Although we target and build our experiments with FPGA-based edge computing platforms, the Kria KV260 and PYNQ-Z2, our system achieves throughput speed-ups by up to 28.37× and 13.11× when compared to an Intel core i7 processor, respectively. Furthermore, our system in the two edge computing platforms is energy-efficiency also when it consumes 3.721 μJPS (μ-joule per sample) and 3.328 μJPS for the PYNQ-Z2 and Kria KV260 platforms, respectively. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: FPGA-based architecture; IoTs edge computing; Random forest
Funding Texts: This research is funded by Vietnam National University Ho Chi Minh City (VNU-HCM) under grant number NCM2021-20-02 . We acknowledge Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology (HCMUT), VNU-HCM for supporting this study.

Authors: Hoang, M.T.T.; Giang Le, G.T.; Kiwao, K.; Duong, H.T.; Nguyen, T.Q.; Phan, T.Q.; Bui, M.Q.; Truong, D.A.; Trinh, H.T.
Author full names: Hoang, Minh Tue Thi (57222960014); Giang Le, Truong (57193000660); Kiwao, Kadokami (58171152400); Duong, Hanh Thi (55914866300); Nguyen, Trung Quang (56033836800); Phan, Thangquang (58171752400); Bui, Minhquang (57205079363); Truong, Dung Anh (57929837000); Trinh, Ha T. (57192998538)
Title: Occurrence and risk of human exposure to organophosphate flame retardants in indoor air and dust in Hanoi, Vietnam
Affiliations: Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Chemistry, Hanoi, Viet Nam; The University of Kitakyushu, Kitakyushu, Japan; Institute of Environmental Technology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Center for Research and Technology Transfer, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le Quy Don Technical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Hoang, Minh Tue Thi, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Le Quy Don Technical University, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Giang Le, Truong, Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Chemistry, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kiwao, Kadokami, The University of Kitakyushu, Kitakyushu, Japan; Duong, Hanh Thi, Institute of Environmental Technology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Trung Quang, Center for Research and Technology Transfer, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Phan, Thangquang, Institute of Environmental Technology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Bui, Minhquang, Center for Research and Technology Transfer, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Truong, Dung Anh, Institute of Environmental Technology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Trinh, Ha T., Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Chemistry, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: The presence and distribution of thirteen organophosphate flame retardants (OPFRs) were investigated in indoor air and dust samples collected in Hanoi, Vietnam. The total OPFRs (ƩOPFRs) concentrations in indoor air and dust samples were 42.3–358 ng m−3 (median 101 ng m−3) and 1290–17,500 ng g−1 (median 7580 ng g−1), respectively. The profile of OPFRs in both indoor air and dust indicated that tris(1-chloro-2-propyl) phosphate (TCIPP) was the most dominant compound with a median concentration of 75.3 ng m−3 and 3620 ng g−1, contributing 75.2% and 46.1% to ƩOPFRs concentrations in indoor air and dust, respectively, followed by tris(2-butoxyethyl) phosphate (TBOEP), with a median concentration of 16.3 ng m−3 and 2500 ng g−1, contributing 14.1% and 33.6% to ƩOPFRs concentrations in indoor air and dust, respectively. The levels of OPFRs in the indoor air samples and corresponding indoor dust samples showed a strong positive correlation. The total estimated daily intakes (EDI<inf>total</inf>) of ƩOPFRs (via air inhalation, dust ingestion, and dermal absorption) for adults and toddlers under the median and high exposure scenarios were 36.7 and 160 ng kg−1 d−1, and 266 and 1270 ng kg−1 d−1, respectively. Among the investigated exposure pathways, dermal absorption was a primary exposure pathway to OPFRs for both toddlers and adults. The hazard quotients (HQ) ranged from 5.31 × 10−8 to 6.47 × 10−2 (<1), and the lifetime cancer risks (LCR) were from 2.05 × 10−11 to 7.37 × 10−8 (<10−6), indicating that human health risks from exposure to OPFRs in indoor environments are not significant. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Human exposure; Indoor air; Indoor dust; Organophosphate flame retardants; Risk assessment

Authors: Nguyen, N.Q.; Dinh, N.C.; Nguyen, H.K.L.; Pham, X.H.; Nguyen Duc, D.K.; Bui, D.T.; Tran, T.P.
Author full names: Nguyen, Tan Quang (57218343212); Dinh, Nguyen Cong (57215201392); Nguyen, Hoang Khanh Linh (58525636600); Pham, Xuan Hung (57382826600); Nguyen Duc, Kien (57204421330); Bui, Duc Tinh (58524742800); Tran, Thi Phuong (58138884400)
Title: Climate change vulnerability and poverty nexus: evidence from coastal communities in central Vietnam
Source title: Journal of Agriculture and Environment for International Development
Affiliations: Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; International School, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Faculty of Economics and Development Studies, University of Economics, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Centre for Climate Change Study in Central Vietnam, University of Agriculture and Forestry, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Tan Quang, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan, International School, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Dinh, Nguyen Cong, Faculty of Economics and Development Studies, University of Economics, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Hoang Khanh Linh, International School, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Pham, Xuan Hung, Faculty of Economics and Development Studies, University of Economics, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Nguyen Duc, Kien, Faculty of Economics and Development Studies, University of Economics, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Bui, Duc Tinh, Faculty of Economics and Development Studies, University of Economics, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Tran, Thi Phuong, Centre for Climate Change Study in Central Vietnam, University of Agriculture and Forestry, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam
Abstract: The vulnerability assessment of small-scale households on the central coast of Vietnam has been inadequate despite the apparent impacts of climate change. This knowledge gap presents challenges for identifying at-risk individuals and communities and could impede effective public policy and resource allocation for adaptation efforts. To address this issue, this study employed the Livelihood Vulnerability Index referencing IPCC definitions (LVI-IPCC) framework to examine livelihood vulnerability and its determinants among 455 small-scale households in the coastal areas of Phu Vang district, Thua Thien Hue province, Vietnam. The LVI-IPCC calculation utilized a database of 11 major and 33 sub-indicators collected through a household survey conducted in 2021. The findings revealed that these households exhibit moderate vulnerability to natural disasters and climate shocks, as reflected by their high sensitivity index scores. Additionally, the study identified a persistent cycle of poverty and livelihood vulnerability among coastal communities, wherein poverty and reliance on nature-based income serve as the root cause of the exposure and a gateway to this loop. This study strongly advocates for a pro-poor approach that places poverty alleviation at the forefront of community development planning and climate change agendas. Under this approach, developing value chain models in agriculture and aquaculture and diversifying livelihoods through activities such as community-based tourism is highly recommended. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Climate change; coastal areas; livelihood vulnerability; poverty; Vietnam

Authors: Nguyen, S.A.; Pham, K.G.; Seidel, C.; Pham, A.H.; Phung, C.N.; Trinh, T.V.
Author full names: Nguyen, Son Anh (59436309500); Pham, Khanh Gia (58405416200); Seidel, Christian (55708560600); Pham, Anh Hoang (57189489240); Phung, Cuong Nhu (58406829600); Trinh, Trung Van (58408982000)
Title: CHANGE IN MICROSTRUCTURE AND HARDNESS OF ADDITIVELY MANUFACTURED AISI H13 STEEL BY HEAT TREATMENT AND NITRIDING PROCESSES
Affiliations: School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Department of Applied Sciences and Mechatronics, Hochschule München, Munich, Germany; Faculty of Materials for Energy, Shimane University, Matsue, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Son Anh, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Pham, Khanh Gia, Department of Applied Sciences and Mechatronics, Hochschule München, Munich, Germany; Seidel, Christian, Department of Applied Sciences and Mechatronics, Hochschule München, Munich, Germany; Pham, Anh Hoang, Faculty of Materials for Energy, Shimane University, Matsue, Japan; Phung, Cuong Nhu, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Trinh, Trung Van, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: AISI H13 steel samples were additively manufactured using a laser powder bed fusion (LPBF) system. The effect of annealing tem-perature, quenching & tempering, and nitriding were determined. The microstructure and properties of the samples were investigated using optical microscopy, scanning electron microscopy, electron backscattered diffraction, electron probe micro-analysis, X-ray diffraction, roughness measurement, and a hardness tester. The results show that the as-built AISI H13 steel sample had a roughness on the surface and pores inside. The microstructure consisted of martensite and retained austenite. The average hardness was 460 HV, and the porosity was 0.086 %. The annealing process helped homogenize the microstructure, increase the density, and reduce the porosity and hardness of the LPBF-manufactured sample. The quenching process helped increase the hardness of the steel to the maximum of 787 HV, then the tempering process reduced the hardness to 572 HV. Heat treatment and nitriding processes tended to increase the martensite block size, reduce the retained austenitic content, and precipitate the V-Mo-rich carbide in the LPBF-manu-factured AISI H13 steel. After nitriding was conducted, the nitriding case depth was 87 μm, and the surface hardness increased up to higher than 1020 HV due to the formation of CrN and Fe3-4N. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: AISI H13 steel; gas nitriding; heat treatment; Laser powder bed fusion (LPBF)

Authors: Jin, R.; Li, Y.; Saito, Y.; Wang, Z.; Oanh Ta, T.K.; Nguyen, V.L.; Yang, J.; Liu, M.; Wu, Y.
Title: Amino accelerators and antioxidants in sediments from the Dong Nai River System, Vietnam: Distribution and influential factors
Affiliations: School of Geographic Sciences, Key Laboratory of Geographic Information Science, Ministry of Education, Shanghai, China; State Key Laboratory of Estuarine and Coastal Research, Shanghai, China; Estuary Research Center, Shimane University, Matsue, Japan; Geological Survey of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; HCMC Institute of Resources Geography, VAST, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ministry of Natural Resources of the People's Republic of China, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Jin, Ruihe, School of Geographic Sciences, Key Laboratory of Geographic Information Science, Ministry of Education, Shanghai, China; Li, Yue, State Key Laboratory of Estuarine and Coastal Research, Shanghai, China; Saito, Yoshiki, Estuary Research Center, Shimane University, Matsue, Japan, Geological Survey of Japan, Tsukuba, Japan; Wang, Zhanghua, State Key Laboratory of Estuarine and Coastal Research, Shanghai, China; Oanh Ta, Thi Kim, HCMC Institute of Resources Geography, VAST, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Van Lap, HCMC Institute of Resources Geography, VAST, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Yang, Jing, School of Geographic Sciences, Key Laboratory of Geographic Information Science, Ministry of Education, Shanghai, China, Ministry of Natural Resources of the People's Republic of China, Beijing, China; Liu, Min, School of Geographic Sciences, Key Laboratory of Geographic Information Science, Ministry of Education, Shanghai, China, Ministry of Natural Resources of the People's Republic of China, Beijing, China; Wu, Yan, School of Geographic Sciences, Key Laboratory of Geographic Information Science, Ministry of Education, Shanghai, China, Ministry of Natural Resources of the People's Republic of China, Beijing, China
Abstract: Amino accelerators and antioxidants (AAL/Os) have become a suite of contaminants of emerging concern recently due to the accumulating evidence for their environmental occurrence and associated toxic potential. Nevertheless, data on sedimentary deposition of AAL/Os has remained scarce, particularly for regions beyond the North America. In the present study, we elucidated spatial distribution of fifteen AAL/Os and five AAO transformation products (AAOTPs) in seventy-seven sediments from the Dong Nai River System (DNRS), Vietnam. Total concentrations of AAL/Os (∑AAL/Os) ranged from 0.377 to 51.4 ng/g (median: 5.01 ng/g). 1,3-Diphenylguanidine and 4,4′-bis(1,1-dimethylbenzyl) diphenylamine were the two most prevalent congeners, both with detection frequencies >80%. Additionally, AAOTPs were quantifiable in 79% of the DNRS sediments with a median ∑AAOTPs at 2.19 ng/g, dominated by N, N′-diphenylbenzidine and 2-nitrodiphenylamine. Higher sediment-associated levels of AAL/Os and AAOTPs were spotted in downstream and the primary tributary of the DNRS compared to the upstream, implying their cumulative sedimentation towards the estuarine region. The distribution patterns of AAL/Os and AAOTPs across individual transects also demonstrated the influence of human activities (e.g., urbanization and agriculture), hydrodynamics, and decontamination by mangrove reserves. Meanwhile, characteristics of sediments, i.e., total organic carbon (TOC) content and grain sizes, exhibited significant correlations with the burdens of these compounds, indicating their preferential partitioning into the fine and TOC-rich matter. This research sheds light on environmental behavior of AAL/Os and AAOTPs beneath Asian aquatic system, and highlights the need for further evaluation of their impacts on the wildlife and public health. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Amino accelerators and antioxidants; Driving factors; Spatial distribution; The Dong Nai River System; Transformation products

Authors: Nguyen, D.-D.; Pham, T.-T.; Le, T.-T.; Do, T.D.; Goto, T.; Yukita, K.
Author full names: Nguyen, Duy Dinh (57190812356); Pham, The Tiep (58069051900); Le, Tat Thang (57210833037); Do, T. D. (55266268300); Goto, Takuya (57222326750); Yukita, Kazuto (6603216799)
Title: Impact of Parameter Mismatch on Three-Phase Dual-Active-Bridge Converters
Affiliations: School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; FPT Software, Richardson, United States; Department of Robotics and Mechatronics, Nazarbayev University, Astana, Kazakhstan; Department of Electrical Engineering, Aichi Institute of Technology, Toyota, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Duy Dinh, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Pham, The Tiep, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Tat Thang, FPT Software, Richardson, United States; Do, T. D., Department of Robotics and Mechatronics, Nazarbayev University, Astana, Kazakhstan; Goto, Takuya, Department of Electrical Engineering, Aichi Institute of Technology, Toyota, Japan; Yukita, Kazuto, Department of Electrical Engineering, Aichi Institute of Technology, Toyota, Japan
Abstract: Three-phase dual active bridge converters (DAB3) are a widely used topology in battery charging applications thanks to their numerous advantages, such as bidirectional power flow, galvanic isolation, low output current ripple, and inherent soft-switching. In such applications, three single-phase transformers are commonly employed as the AC-link to simplify manufacturing and reduce costs. These transformers’ leakage inductance can be utilized instead of the external leakage inductance to achieve high power density. However, the assumption of uniformity in these inductances is not always accurate as they can vary significantly during fabrication. This study presents a comprehensive analysis of the impact of transformer leakage inductance variation, which can deviate by up to 24% from the desired value. The effects of this variation are investigated from different perspectives, including power transfer, soft-switching range, root-mean-square (RMS) current, and the temperature rise of the transformer winding. Although the power transfer and total copper loss of transformers are changed insignificantly even under highly mismatched leakage inductance, the currents and thermal distribution among phases are considerably impacted. Based on statistical probability, a maximum leakage inductance variation threshold of 10–15% compared to the desired value is recommended to ensure the maximum acceptable temperature rise among phases. Experimental results are presented to validate the analysis. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: leakage inductance; parameter mismatch; standard deviation; thermal management; three-phase dual-active-bridge
Funding Texts: This research is funded by Hanoi University of Science and Technology (HUST) under project number T2021-SAHEP-005.

Authors: Mai, L.N.; Vu, T.H.; Dinh, T.X.; Vu, H.D.; Tran, C.-D.; Dau, V.T.; Ngo, H.K.

Title: Numerical study of electrohydrodynamic atomization considering liquid wetting and corona discharge effects
Affiliations: Department of Aerospace Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; School of Engineering and Built Environment, Griffith University, Brisbane, Australia; Division of Research and Development, Explosion Research Institute Inc., Tokyo, Japan; School of Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, University of Southern Queensland, Toowoomba, Australia; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam

Abstract: In this paper, the behavior of the cone-jet mode of fluid by electrohydrodynamic atomization (electrospray) is numerically simulated and investigated with the effect of liquid wetting and corona discharge effects. The simulation was performed with contact angle condition to fit the Taylor cone shape by experiments. Experimental data are provided to verify and validate the numerical method, followed by additional analyses on the effects of electrical conductivity, surface tension, flow rate, and fluid viscosity on the electrospray characteristics, including spray current and jet diameter. Numerical results by simulations are in reasonable agreement with experiments and consistent with the literature. Analyses on different contact angles suggest potentially major impacts of this factor on the cone-jet mode in high voltage and low flow rate circumstances. Furthermore, the influence of corona discharge on electrospray is also investigated by both electrospray-corona simulation and experiment using a high-speed camera, yielding a significant improvement in the numerical prediction for Taylor cone formation. Numerical results indicate that liquid wetting on capillary nozzles would be a vital factor for the Taylor cone formation in numerical electrospray-corona discharge studies. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Atomization; Contact angle; Electric corona; Electrohydrodynamics; High speed cameras; Numerical methods; Condition; Cone shape; Cone-jet mode; Corona discharges; Discharge effects; Electrical conductivity; Electrohydrodynamic atomization; Electrosprays; Numerical results; Taylor cone; Wetting

Authors: Qureshi, S.; Phan-Van, L.; Nguyen, L.D.; Nguyen, T.D.
Author full names: Qureshi, Shahab (58177439000); Phan-Van, Long (57954477700); Nguyen, Linh Dan (59272669000); Nguyen, Duc Tuyen (58279068400)
Title: Rooftop solar policies feasibility assessment model: Vietnam case study
Affiliations: SQ-Associates, Australia; Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Department of Economics, School of Economics and Management, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Qureshi, Shahab, SQ-Associates, Australia; Phan-Van, Long, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Linh Dan, Department of Economics, School of Economics and Management, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Duc Tuyen, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The Vietnam government has promulgated many incentive policies to promote rooftop solar development, due to electricity supply–demand pressure and Vietnam's net-zero emissions commitments. Although the impact of these policies is tremendous in increasing solar energy capacity, the latest policy for solar power expired at the end of 2020. To support the Vietnam government in promulgating the next incentive policy, this paper proposes a feasibility assessment model for rooftop solar policies, which enables the viability evaluation of policies from the perspective of both utility/entity and customer. By utilizing the policy options customized by users, the model generates a significant amount of technical and financial output to appreciate the impacts of potential policies under different scenarios. Five policy options have been simulated and evaluated using the proposed model. The output data shows the importance of the FIT rate in establishing the feasibility of a rooftop solar project, where the higher the FIT rate, the lower the feasibility for the utility, and vice versa. By using the output data from the proposed model, policymakers can have a better view of the impacts of different policies under different scenarios, which results in the development and implementation of more impactful policies. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Assessment model; Feed in Tariff; Net Metering; Rooftop solar policy

Abstract: The simultaneous nitrification and denitrification (SND) process requires little to no external carbon or oxygen sources; thus, it is a revolutionary approach for treating municipal wastewater because of both economic and environmental benefits. This review provided an overview of the microbial communities, techniques to detect them in nitrogen removal systems, and SND mechanisms related to functional microorganisms and enzymes in flocs as well as biofilms. A thorough discussion of the dynamics of microbial communities under important conditions such as dissolved oxygen and C/N ratio was provided. The environmental effects in terms of greenhouse gas emission and energy consumption, as well as the difficulties and potential future applications of adopting SND in municipal wastewater treatment for environmental sustainability, were also covered. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Nguyen, P.T.T.; Kimura, A.

Title: Disclosure characteristics of annual reports and information asymmetry: Evidence from foreign firms listed on the US stock exchange
Affiliations: University of Economics - The University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Graduate School of International Social Sciences, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Phuong Thi Thuy, University of Economics - The University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Kimura, Akihisa, Graduate School of International Social Sciences, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: This research examines the associations between two of the most interesting disclosure characteristics of annual reports and information asymmetry. It illustrates that the length of annual reports is negatively associated with information asymmetry. By contrast, our research shows that an improvement in the readability of annual reports does not positively affect information asymmetry among investors. Our research assumes the current tendency of annual reports does not worsen the information environments for investors in extracting the information. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Annual reports; Information asymmetry; Length; Readability

Authors: Pham, N.V.; Ohgaki, K.; Hattori, M.; Miyashita, T.; Hidekuma, Y.
Author full names: Pham, Ngoc Vinh (57211567631); Ohgaki, Kazuo (36134829700); Hattori, Masafumi (57208900485); Miyashita, Takeshi (7201920776); Hidekuma, Yuya (25027332000)
Title: Seismic Retrofit of Diagonal Tension Members in Steel Deck-Truss Bridges Using CFRP Sheets
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Dept. of Building Technologists, Institute of Technologists, Gyoda, Japan; Nippon Expressway Research Institute Company Limited, Machida, Japan; Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Nippon Steel Corporation, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Pham, Ngoc Vinh, Department of Civil Engineering, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Ohgaki, Kazuo, Dept. of Building Technologists, Institute of Technologists, Gyoda, Japan; Hattori, Masafumi, Nippon Expressway Research Institute Company Limited, Machida, Japan; Miyashita, Takeshi, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Hidekuma, Yuya, Nippon Steel Corporation, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: This study entailed axial cyclic loading tests conducted on full-scale diagonal tension members of steel deck-truss bridges to evaluate the effects of seismic retrofitting methods using carbon fiber-reinforced polymer (CFRP) sheets. The loading tests were performed on CFRP-retrofitted specimens with varying anchoring lengths of the CFRP sheets. The results indicated that the proposed retrofitting methods, which employed the intermediate-modulus CFRP type (390-450 GPa) and polyurea putty (a ductile adhesive), delayed the plastic buckling of the flanges and substantially increased the load-carrying capacities, stiffnesses, and ductility capacities of the retrofitted diagonal tension members. Additionally, the polyurea putty effectively suppressed the peeling failure of the CFRP sheets. It maintained the cross-sectional integrity between the steel members and CFRP sheets even after the plastic buckling of the flanges and rupture failure of the CFRP sheets. Further, finite-element analyses accurately reproduced the loading test results by considering the nonlinear bond-slip performance of polyurea putty, anisotropic characteristics of the CFRP sheets, and cyclic plasticity properties of steel. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Effects of physical properties and undrained cyclic shear conditions on the pore water pressure responses of saturated sands and clays
Affiliations: University of Sciences, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan; Institute of Geological Sciences, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Thanh Nhan, Tran, University of Sciences, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Matsuda, Hiroshi, Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan; Phuong An, Tran Thi, University of Sciences, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Thanh Nhan, Nguyen Thi, University of Sciences, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; van Tiens, Pham, Institute of Geological Sciences, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thien, Do Quang, University of Sciences, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam
Abstract: For clarifying the effects of relative density (Dr) and Atterberg’s limits on the cyclic shear-induced pore water pressure properties of soils, sandy soils with similar index properties and clayey soils with different Atteberg’s limits were collected from Vietnam and Japan and used for this study. Specimens atDr= 50% of Nam O sand and Dr= 70% of Toyoura sand, and those of Hue clay and Japanese Kaolin clay were consolidated under the vertical stress of σνο = 49 kPa. They were then subjected to undrained cyclic shear for various cyclic shear directions and wide ranges of the number of cycles and shear strain amplitudes. Under the same cyclic shearing conditions, specimens of sand at higher Dr (Toyoura sand) and clay with higher Atterberg’s limits (Kaolin) show a lower pore water pressure ratio. The number of cycles and the cumulative shear strain at the starting point of pore water pressure generation were observed for different soils and testing conditions. In addition, using the cumulative shear strain, a new strain path parameter, the effects of shear strain amplitude and cyclic shear direction can be captured, resulting in a unique - G* relation on each soil. Based on this, fitting lines can be drawn and referred to promote a prediction of the cyclic shear-induced pore water pressure accumulation for the used soils under different cyclic shear conditions. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Atterberg’s limits; clay; cyclic shear condition; pore water pressure; relative densify; sand

Title: Insight into the direct conversion of methane to methanol on modified ZIF-204 from the perspective of DFT-based calculations
Affiliations: Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Department of Mathematics and Physics, VNUHCM - University of Information Technology, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Department of Theoretical Physics, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Key Laboratory for Multiscale Simulation of Complex Systems, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Department of Physics and Nanotechnology, SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur, India; School of Physics, Suranaree University of Technology, Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand; Culham Centre for Fusion Energy, Abingdon, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Le, Thong Nguyen Minh, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Le, Thu Bao Nguyen, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Department of Mathematics and Physics, VNUHCM - University of Information Technology, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Phat Tan, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Department of Theoretical Physics, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Trang Thuy M., Key Laboratory for Multiscale Simulation of Complex Systems, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tran, Quang Ngoc, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Toan The, Key Laboratory for Multiscale Simulation of Complex Systems, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan, Department of Physics and Nanotechnology, SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Kattankulathur, India, School of Physics, Suranaree University of Technology, Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand; Phan, Thang Bach, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen-Manh, Duc, Culham Centre for Fusion Energy, Abingdon, United Kingdom
Abstract: Direct oxidation of methane over oxo-doped ZIF-204, a bio-mimetic metal-organic framework, is investigated under first-principles calculations based on density functional theory. In the pristine ZIF-204, the tetrahedral methane molecule anchors to an open monocopper site via the so-called η2 configuration with a physisorption energy of 0.24 eV. This weak binding arises from an electrostatic interaction between the negative charge of carbon in the methane molecule and the positive Cu2+ cation in the framework. In the modified ZIF-204, the doped oxo species is stabilized at the axial position of a CuN<inf>4</inf>-base square pyramid at a distance of 2.06 Å. The dative covalent bond between Cu and oxo is responsible for the formation energy of 1.06 eV. With the presence of the oxo group, the presenting of electrons in the O_p<inf>z</inf> orbital accounts for the adsorption of methane via hydrogen bonding with an adsorption energy of 0.30 eV. The methane oxidation can occur via either a concerted direct oxo insertion mechanism or a hydrogen-atom abstraction radical rebound mechanism. Calculations on transition-state barriers show that reactions via the concerted direct oxo insertion mechanism can happen without energy barriers. Concerning the hydrogen-atom abstraction radical rebound mechanism, the C-H bond dissociation of the CH<inf>4</inf> molecule is barrierless, but the C-O bond recombination to form the CH<inf>3</inf>OH molecule occurs through a low barrier of 0.16 eV. These predictions suggest the modified ZIF-204 is a promising catalyst for methane oxidization. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Four new subspecies of butterflies (Lepidoptera, Papilionoidea) from Phu Quoc Island, southern Vietnam
Affiliations: Research Institute of Evolution Biology, Tokyo, Japan; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Tamamitsu, Saito, Research Institute of Evolution Biology, Tokyo, Japan; van Lien, Vu, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: We describe and illustrate four new subspecies of Papilionoidea butterflies which were collected from Phu Quoc Island, Kien Giang province, southern Vietnam between 2006 and 2017. These are papilionid Graphium antiphates matsui T. Saito & Vu subspec. nov.; Nymphalidae: Tanaecia julii due T. Saito & Vu, subspec. nov.; Cynitia lepidea phuquoca T. Saito & Vu, subspec. nov.; and Bassarona teuta anh T. Saito & Vu, subspec. nov. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Nguyen, V.-T.; Tran, V.-M.; Ngoc-Tam, N.-T.
Author full names: Nguyen, Tinh Hong Phuong (57226685512); Tran, Vu Minh (58298880900); Ngoc-Tam, Bui (57212681073)
Title: Self-Adaptive Differential Evolution with Gauss Distribution for Optimal Mechanism Design
Affiliations: School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Department of Machinery and Control Systems, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Tinh Hong Phuong, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tran, Vu Minh, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ngoc-Tam, Bui, Department of Machinery and Control Systems, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Differential evolution (DE) is one of the best evolutionary algorithms (EAs). In recent decades, many techniques have been developed to enhance the performance of this algorithm, such as the Improve Self-Adaptive Differential Evolution (ISADE) algorithm. Based on the analysis of the aspects that may improve the performance of ISADE, we proposed a modified ISADE version with applying the Gauss distribution for mutation procedure. In ISADE, to determine the scaling factor (F), the population is ranked, then, based on the rank number, population size, and current generation, the formula of the Sigmoid function is used. In the proposed algorithm, F is amplified by a factor which is generated based on Gaussian distribution. It has the potential to enhance the variety of population. In comparison with several reference algorithms regarding converging speed and the consistency of optimal solutions, the simulation results reveal the performance of the suggested algorithm is exceptional. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: differential evolution; Gauss distribution; mutation procedure; optimization algorithm

Authors: Ma, K.-M.; Le, D.-H.; Pham, C.-K.; Hoang, T.-T.
Author full names: Ma, Khai Minh (57415300900); Le, Duc Hung (55426426100); Pham, Cong Kha (56186480400); Hoang, Trong Thuc (56024762000)
Title: Design of an SoC Based on 32-Bit RISC-V Processor with Low-Latency Lightweight Cryptographic Cores in FPGA
Affiliations: Faculty of Electronics and Telecommunications, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Department of Computer and Network Engineering, The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ma, Khai Minh, Faculty of Electronics and Telecommunications, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Le, Duc Hung, Faculty of Electronics and Telecommunications, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Pham, Cong Kha, Department of Computer and Network Engineering, The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan; Hoang, Trong Thuc, Department of Computer and Network Engineering, The University of Electro-Communications, Chofu, Japan
Abstract: The security of Internet of Things (IoTs) devices in recent years has created interest in developing implementations of lightweight cryptographic algorithms for such systems. Additionally, open-source hardware and field-programable gate arrays (FPGAs) are gaining traction via newly developed tools, frameworks, and HDLs. This enables new methods of creating hardware and systems faster, more simply, and more efficiently. In this paper, the implementation of a system-on-chip (SoC) based on a 32-bit RISC-V processor with lightweight cryptographic accelerator cores in FPGA and an open-source integrating framework is presented. The system consists of a 32-bit VexRiscv processor, written in SpinalHDL, and lightweight cryptographic accelerator cores for the PRINCE block cipher, the PRESENT-80 block cipher, the ChaCha stream cipher, and the SHA3-512 hash function, written in Verilog HDL and optimized for low latency with fewer clock cycles. The primary aim of this work was to develop a customized SoC platform with a register-controlled bus suitable for integrating lightweight cryptographic cores to become compact embedded systems that require encryption functionalities. Additionally, custom firmware was developed to verify the functionality of the SoC with all integrated accelerator cores, and to evaluate the speed of cryptographic processing. The proposed system was successfully implemented in a Xilinx Nexys4 DDR FPGA development board. The resources of the system in the FPGA were low with 11,830 LUTs and 9552 FFs. The proposed system can be applicable to enhancing the security of Internet of Things systems. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: FPGA; lightweight cryptography; RISC-V; system-on-chip; VexRiscv

Title: Meromorphic nearby cycle functors and monodromies of meromorphic functions (with Appendix by T. Saito)

Abstract: We introduce meromorphic nearby cycle functors and study their functorial properties. Moreover we apply them to monodromies of meromorphic functions in various situations. Combinatorial descriptions of their reduced Hodge spectra and Jordan normal forms will be obtained. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Trinh, Hoang Nghia (58189765600); Vu, Toan Khanh (57436238200); Vu, Cam Tu (57208881188); Oanh, Nguyen Thi Kieu (57507112600); van Anh, Nguyen Thi (59778460200); Le, Hoang Luyen (57218500601); Negishi, Nobuaki (55676242300); Ouillon, Sylvain (56202366100); van Hoi, Bui (57208887356)
Title: Removal of Carbamazepine in Aqueous Solution by TiO2 Ceramic Photo-Catalyst under Simulated Solar Light: Kinetics, Effects of Environmental Factors and Degradation Pathways
Affiliations: Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Environmental Management Research Institute, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Université de Toulouse, Toulouse, France
Authors with affiliations: Trinh, Hoang Nghia, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vu, Toan Khanh, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vu, Cam Tu, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Oanh, Nguyen Thi Kieu, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; van Anh, Nguyen Thi, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Hoang Luyen, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Negishi, Nobuaki, Environmental Management Research Institute, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Ouillon, Sylvain, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Université de Toulouse, Toulouse, France; van Hoi, Bui, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Current research on the photocatalytic activity of TiO<inf>2</inf> mainly focuses on its nano- or micro-particle forms, which are difficult to recycle and apply in real engineering applications. This study aims to apply a small pilot of TiO<inf>2</inf> in the ceramic form to remove carbamazepine (CBZ) from an aqueous solution under simulated sunlight. A high removal efficiency up to >99% was shown in a 5 mg L−1 CBZ solution after 6 h of irradiation with a total energy of 150.92 kJ. The kinetic degradation was not affected in an alkaline solution (at pH 7, pH 10, and pH 13) but was faster under acidic conditions (pH 2) in which CBZ existed in the protonated form. The presence of NO<inf>3</inf>− (10–50 mg L−1) slightly affected the photodegradation of CBZ while humic acid significantly reduced the photocatalytic activity. In addition, the presence of major ions in water also had a negative effect at concentrations between 10 and 50 mg L−1. The MS/MS was used to identify the transformation products of CBZ, and a possible degradation mechanism was proposed. The toxicity of CBZ and the by-products was primarily evaluated. The results showed that TiO<inf>2</inf> ceramics show high reusability and stability with a photocatalytic performance of >95% and a mass loss of <5% after 90 degradation cycles. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Phuong, T.T.; Nguyen, N.Q.; Hai, N.T.; Ngu, N.H.
Author full names: Phuong, Tran Thi (57194073500); Nguyen, Tan Quang (57218343212); Hai, Nguyenthi (58199385200); Ngu, Nguyen Huu (57654503700)
Title: Reframing Climate Change Resilience: An Intersectional Perspective of Ethnicity and Gender from Vietnam
Affiliations: Centre for Climate Change Study in Central Vietnam, University of Agriculture and Forestry, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Faculty of Land Resources and Agricultural Environment, University of Agriculture and Forestry, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Okayama University, Okayama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Phuong, Tran Thi, Centre for Climate Change Study in Central Vietnam, University of Agriculture and Forestry, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam, Faculty of Land Resources and Agricultural Environment, University of Agriculture and Forestry, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Tan Quang, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Hai, Nguyenthi, Faculty of Land Resources and Agricultural Environment, University of Agriculture and Forestry, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Ngu, Nguyen Huu, Faculty of Land Resources and Agricultural Environment, University of Agriculture and Forestry, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam
Abstract: This study breaks away from traditional macroeconomic-data-based research that often overlooks the subjective experiences of communities and social groups in assessing their resilience to external stressors. Instead, we conducted a nuanced analysis of self-assessments provided by 364 household heads in the Nam Dong District, Thua Thien Hue Province, Vietnam, to gain a comprehensive understanding of household resilience. Our investigation focused on two upland communities—the Kinh majority and Co Tu ethnic minority households—evaluating their resilience levels in terms of the five livelihood capitals and identifying significant disparities among different ethnic and gender groups. Our findings reveal notable differences in livelihood resilience to climate change and variability among these groups, particularly for women, the poor, and ethnic minorities who exhibit lower resilience levels. This underscores the need for policies and programs designed to improve resilience capacity while taking into account these groups’ cultural and social norms. We suggest focusing on improving financial, human, and social capitals to increase households’ resilience to external shocks. Specifically, building resilience for disadvantaged groups must go hand in hand with promoting their overall well-being and alleviating poverty. Additionally, we recommend tailored training programs to raise awareness among households and strengthening institutional systems to enhance overall resilience. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: climate change and variability; intersectional perspective; livelihood resilience; Vietnam
Index Keywords: climate change; climate variation; ethnic minority; gender; household survey; livelihood; Nam Dong; Thua Thien Hue; Viet Nam

Authors: Nguyen, N.Q.; van Chuong, H.; Khanh Linh, N.H.; Tung, P.G.; Dinh, N.C.; Anh Tuyet, T.T.
Author full names: Nguyen, Tan Quang (57218343212); van Chuong, Huynh (56668777400); Khanh Linh, Nguyen Hoang (58187052500); Tung, Pham Gia (57579312800); Dinh, Nguyen Cong (57215201392); Anh Tuyet, Tran Thi (58186938800)
Title: Climate shocks and responses: Perspectives and experiences of ethnic minority farmers in rural mountainous regions of Central Vietnam
Affiliations: International School, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; University of Economics, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; University of Agriculture and Forestry, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Tan Quang, International School, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; van Chuong, Huynh, International School, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Khanh Linh, Nguyen Hoang, International School, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Tung, Pham Gia, International School, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Dinh, Nguyen Cong, University of Economics, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Anh Tuyet, Tran Thi, University of Agriculture and Forestry, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam
Abstract: Ethnic minority farmers (EMFs) in upland areas of Central Vietnam are particularly vulnerable to the impacts of climate shocks and extreme events. It is thus urgent to examine their perceptions of the potential risks, their coping strategies, and the factors influencing their adaptation decisions in agriculture production. By exploring adaptation measures of the Xo Dang and Co Tu EMFs in Quang Nam province, Central Vietnam, the study results reveal that the EMFs are increasingly conscious of local climate shocks in the recent decade; as a result, they have applied multiple specific strategies in agriculture production to mitigate risks. The findings indicate that the key variables of the age of the household head, income, household size, residence period at the locality, and farmers' perception of climate change significantly influenced the households’ adaptation decisions. Recognizing this, the study proposed specific recommendations and policy implications to minimize risks while maximizing benefits for the EMFs. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Adaptation decisions; Agriculture production; Central Vietnam; Climate change; Ethnic minority farmers (EMFs)

Authors: Nguyen, D.-D.; Pham, T.-T.; Le, T.-T.; Choi, S.; Yukita, K.
Author full names: Nguyen, Duy Dinh (57190812356); Pham, The Tiep (58069051900); Le, Tat Thang (57210833037); Choi, Sewan (7408119103); Yukita, Kazuto (6603216799)
Title: A Modulation Method for Three-Phase Dual-Active-Bridge Converters in Battery Charging Applications
Affiliations: School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Department of Electronic and Information Engineering, Seoul National University of Science and Technology, Seoul, South Korea; Department of Electrical Engineering, Aichi Institute of Technology, Toyota, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Duy Dinh, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Pham, The Tiep, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Tat Thang, Department of Electronic and Information Engineering, Seoul National University of Science and Technology, Seoul, South Korea; Choi, Sewan, Department of Electronic and Information Engineering, Seoul National University of Science and Technology, Seoul, South Korea; Yukita, Kazuto, Department of Electrical Engineering, Aichi Institute of Technology, Toyota, Japan
Abstract: The Three-phase Dual-Active-Bridge (DAB3) converters are a common choice for quick charging stations for batteries in electric vehicles due to their high power density, versatility, and galvanic isolation capability. However, the DAB3 topology has limited soft-switching range, particularly under light load conditions when the voltage conversion ratio differs significantly from unity, resulting in hard switching, increased loss, and higher electromagnetic interference. To address these issues, various techniques have been proposed, but they often lead to other problems such as higher current ripple or unbalanced thermal distribution. In this paper, a new modulation scheme, called symmetric duty-cycle control (SDM), is proposed for DAB3 converters to overcome these issues. A multiaspect comparison of SDM was conducted against two existing techniques, SPS and ADCC, and its superiority was validated through simulation and experimental results. Our proposed SDM scheme provides a current ripple within 10% to 15% of the average current and enables zero current switching for the whole voltage and power ranges. Additionally, a modified version of SDM can even improve overall efficiency by 7% compared to the conventional SPS technique. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: asymmetric duty-cycle control; dual active bridge; single-phase-shift; symmetric duty-cycle control
Index Keywords: electric vehicle; electromagnetic method; equipment component; experimental study; model validation; topology
