Authors: Bach, M.X.; Minh, T.N.; Anh, D.T.N.; Anh, H.N.; Le-Viet, L.V.; Trung, N.Q.; Bui, M.Q.; Xuan, T.D.
Author full names: Bach, Mai Xuan (57223277619); Minh, Truongngoc (58159365100); Anh, Dao Thi Ngoc (58910496700); Anh, Ho Ngoc (57213232055); Le-Viet, Anh (35329828900); Trung, Nguyen Quang (55961888000); Bui, Minhquang (57205079363); Xuan, T. D. (7003473828)
Title: Protection and Rehabilitation Effects of Cordyceps militaris Fruit Body Extract and Possible Roles of Cordycepin and Adenosine
Affiliations: Department of General and Inorganic Chemistry, Hanoi College of Pharmacy, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Center for Research and Technology Transfer, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Biotechnology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Transdisciplinary Science and Engineering Program, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan; Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan

D., Transdisciplinary Science and Engineering Program, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, Japan
Abstract: Cordyceps militaris is a valued medicinal fungus in folk medicine in East Asia. It contains two major nucleosides, cordycepin and adenosine, which have been reported to have potential antineoplastic, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory activities. This paper aimed to study the effect of C. militaris extract on the reproductive function of a mouse model, evaluating possible toxicity, androgenic activity, and protective and rehabilitative effects against damages caused by sodium valproate (VPA). There was no death and abnormalities observed in mice. Androgen activity was also shown in young male rats by an improvement in several sexual organs. The protective effect of C. militaris extract was explained by the gain of sexual organs’ weight, testosterone concentration, and seminiferous tubule size as well as the enhancement of sperm density, alive sperm percentage, and the progressive forward movement of sperm. The pregnancy rate of female rats paired with VPA-administered male rats (500 mg/kg/day) increased proportionally with the higher dose of C. militaris extract. In the rehabilitation study, an incline in the weight of the Cowper’s gland and glans (0.112 g/kg/day) and testicle and prostate (0.336 g/kg/day) as well as an improvement of the sperm forward progressive movement was observed. The percentage of unprogressive sperm and immotile sperm has reduced. These results suggest that C. militaris is a potential supplement to reduce the negative effects of VPA and improve reproductive function, in which the two major constituents cordycepin and adenosine may play an active role. © 2024 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Cordyceps militaris; mouse model; protective activity; rehabilitation activity; sodium valproate

Title: Comprehensive Analysis of Organic Micropollutants in Fine Particulate Matter in Hanoi Metropolitan Area, Vietnam
Affiliations: Center for Research and Technology Transfer, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Department of Chemistry, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan

Abstract: Rapid urbanization has led to increased environmental pollution in Vietnam, especially air pollution issues. In this study, we used gas chromatography-mass spectrometry with an automated identification and quantification system database to detect and quantitate compounds in atmospheric fine particulate matter (PM<inf>2.5</inf>). A total of 288 compounds classified in 19 pollutant categories based on their origins were detected in PM<inf>2.5</inf> samples collected in three areas of Hanoi during winter. The total content of substances detected ranged from 41.08 to 795.00 ng.m−3. The characteristics and concentrations of organic pollutants differed among the industrial, urban, and agricultural sampling areas, with average concentrations of 179.00, 112.10, and 529.40 ng.m−3, respectively. In this comprehensive study on trace organic compounds conducted with samples collected at three sites, we investigating the basic impact of three main factors on the environment. This study contributes to the literature by providing a data set on the content of trace organic substances in the air at the study site. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Nonlinear Extended Observer-Based ADRC for a Lower-Limb PAM-Based Exoskeleton
Affiliations: School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Faculty of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hanoi Vocational College of High Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Department of Machinery and Control Systems, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan

Abstract: In lower-limb rehabilitation systems, exoskeleton robots are one of the most important components. These robots help patients to execute repetitive exercises under the guidance of physiotherapists. Recently, pneumatic artificial muscles (PAM), a kind of actuator that acts similarly to human muscles, have been chosen to power the exoskeleton robot for better human–machine interaction. In order to enhance the performance of a PAM-based exoskeleton robot, this article implements an active disturbance rejection control (ADRC) strategy with a nonlinear extended state observer (NLESO). Moreover, the stability of the closed-loop system is proved by Lyapunov’s theory. Finally, the experimental results show that with the proposed control strategy, the rehabilitation robot can effectively track the desired trajectories even when under external disturbance. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: active disturbance rejection control; gait training device; nonlinear extended state observer; pneumatic artificial muscle

Authors: Nguyen, T.T.; Thao Nguyen, T.; Nguyen, T.H.; Nguyen, P.L.
Author full names: Nguyen, Trung Thanh (57387571100); Thao Nguyen, Truong (59158659000); Nguyen, Thanh Hung (57674974300); Nguyen, Phile (56244958800)
Title: Fuzzy Q-Learning-Based Opportunistic Communication for MEC-Enhanced Vehicular Crowdsensing
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
Affiliations: School of Information and Communication Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Department of Information Technology and Human Factors, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Trung Thanh, School of Information and Communication Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thao Nguyen, Truong, Department of Information Technology and Human Factors, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba, Japan; Nguyen, Thanh Hung, School of Information and Communication Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Phile, School of Information and Communication Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: This study focuses on MEC-enhanced, vehicle-based crowdsensing systems that rely on devices installed on automobiles. We investigate an opportunistic communication paradigm in which devices can transmit measured data directly to a crowdsensing server over a 4G communication channel or to nearby devices or so-called Road Side Units positioned along the road via Wi-Fi. We tackle a new problem that is how to reduce the cost of 4G while preserving the latency. We propose an offloading strategy that combines a reinforcement learning technique known as Q-learning with Fuzzy logic to accomplish the purpose. Q-learning assists devices in learning to decide the communication channel. Meanwhile, Fuzzy logic is used to optimize the reward function in Q-learning. The experiment results show that our offloading method significantly cuts down around 30-40% of the 4G communication cost while keeping the latency of 99% packets below the required threshold. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: fuzzy logic; MEC; opportunistic communication; reinforcement learning; Vehicle-based mobile crowdsensing
Index Keywords: Computer circuits; Cost benefit analysis; Fuzzy logic; Job analysis; Roads and streets; Vehicle to vehicle communications; Communications channels; Crowdsensing; Fuzzy-Logic; MEC; Opportunistic communications; Q-learning; Reinforcement learnings; Resource management; Task analysis; Vehicle-based mobile crowdsensing; Reinforcement learning

Title: Prevalence of early skin-to-skin contact and its impact on exclusive breastfeeding during the maternity hospitalization
Affiliations: School of Medicine and Pharmacy, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; University of Medicine and Pharmacy at HCMC, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thai Nguyen University of Medicine and Pharmacy, Thai Nguyen City, Viet Nam; Department of Internal Medicine, University of Medicine and Pharmacy at HCMC, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; School of Tropical Medicine and Global Health, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Giang, Hoang Thi Nam, School of Medicine and Pharmacy, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Duy, Do Thi Thuy, School of Medicine and Pharmacy, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Vuong, Nguyen Lam, University of Medicine and Pharmacy at HCMC, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ngoc, Nguyen Thi Tu, Thai Nguyen University of Medicine and Pharmacy, Thai Nguyen City, Viet Nam; Pham, Thu Thi, School of Medicine and Pharmacy, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Tuan, Lequang, School of Medicine and Pharmacy, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Oai, Le, School of Medicine and Pharmacy, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; do Thuc Anh, Pham, School of Medicine and Pharmacy, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Khanh, Ton That, School of Medicine and Pharmacy, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Thi, Nguyen Thi Anh, School of Medicine and Pharmacy, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Luu, Maingoc, Department of Internal Medicine, University of Medicine and Pharmacy at HCMC, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nga, Tran Thi Tuyet, University of Medicine and Pharmacy at HCMC, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Hieu, Le Tho Minh, School of Medicine and Pharmacy, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Huy, Nguyen Tien, School of Tropical Medicine and Global Health, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan
Abstract: Background: Early essential newborn care has been implemented in countries regardless high or low neonatal mortality. This study aims to investigate the current practice of skin-to-skin contact (SSC) and its effect on exclusive breastfeeding during the hospital stay. Methods: This is a cross-sectional study of 1812 Vietnamese mothers in multicenter. A questionnaire answered by the mothers was used to assess the duration of both SSC and breastfeeding practices. Multivariable logistic regression was used to identify a dose–response relationship between early SSC and prevalence of exclusive breastfeeding in hospital. Results: There were 88.7% of mothers experiencing SSC with their infants right after birth and the highest prevalence of SSC was found in district hospitals. Among those experiencing SSC, 18.8% of the infants received more than 90 min of SSC and completed the first breastfeeding during SSC time. Prevalence of exclusive breastfeeding during maternity hospital stay was 46.7%. We found a significant dose–response relation between the duration of SSC and exclusive breastfeeding in hospital. Compared with infants without SSC, the prevalence of exclusive breastfeeding was higher in infants who experienced SSC for 15–90 min (adjusted odds ratio [aOR], 95% confidence interval [95%-CI]: 2.62 [1.61–4.27]) and more than 90 min (aOR [95%-CI]: 5.98 [3.48–10.28]). Completed first breastfeeding during SSC time (aOR [95%-CI]: 4.24 [3.28–5.47]) and being born in district hospitals (aOR [95%-CI]: 2.35 [1.79–3.09]) were associated with increased prevalence of exclusive breastfeeding during hospital stay. On the other hand, mother education level as high school/intermediate (aOR [95%-CI]: 0.58 [0.42–0.82]) and place of residence classified as rural decreased odds of exclusive breastfeeding in hospital (aOR [95%-CI]: 0.78 [0.61–0.99]). Conclusion: Our results demonstrate a strong dose–response relationship between duration of SSC and exclusive breastfeeding in hospital. Interventions that support exclusive breastfeeding during hospital stay, especially achieving prolonged uninterrupted SSC, could improve the duration of breastfeeding. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: van Quan, L.; Nguyen, M.H.; Nguyen, T.H.; Nguyen, K.; Nguyen, P.L.
Author full names: van Quan, La (57192703015); Nguyen, Minh Hieu (57220858708); Nguyen, Thanh Hung (57674974300); Nguyen, Kien (24315251000); Nguyen, Phile (56244958800)
Title: On the Global Maximization of Network Lifetime in Wireless Rechargeable Sensor Networks
Affiliations: School of Information and Communication Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Chiba University, Chiba, Japan
Authors with affiliations: van Quan, La, School of Information and Communication Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Minh Hieu, School of Information and Communication Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Thanh Hung, School of Information and Communication Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Kien, Chiba University, Chiba, Japan; Nguyen, Phile, School of Information and Communication Technology, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: In a Wireless Rechargeable Sensor Network (WRSN), a mobile charger (MC) moves and supplies energy for sensor nodes to maintain the network operation. Hence, optimizing the charging schedule of MC is essential to maximize the network lifetime in WRSNs. The existing works only target the local optimization of network lifetime limited to MC's subsequent charging round. The network lifetime has been normally reflected in a different metric that is not directly related to the final charging round period. To the best of our knowledge, this work is the first to address the global maximization of network lifetime in WRSNs, which optimizes not only the subsequent charging round but all charging rounds over the entire network lifetime. Another uniqueness is the joint consideration of both the charging path and charging time optimization problems. As a solution, we propose a genetic algorithm (GA)-based global optimization scheme that considers all the possible charging rounds. The GA has a novel mutation operation that mutates gene sizes for representing charging schedules with a varying number of charging rounds. The experiment results show that our algorithm can extend the network lifetime by 35.1 times on average and 38.6 times in the best case compared to existing ones. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Three new national records from Kon Chu Rang Nature Reserve, Vietnam: Euphorbia bokorensis, Glochidion geoffrayi and Lysimachia nutantiflora

Abstract: We report three species of angiosperms found in Kon Chu Rang Nature Reserve representing new records for Vietnam. Kon Chu Rang Nature Reserve is located in the Central Highlands of Vietnam, being a part of a recently established Kon Ha Nung Highland Biosphere Reserve. Euphorbia bokorensis (Euphorbiaceae) appears to be widely distributed throughout the Central Highlands of Vietnam, although it was earlier known from Cambodia and Laos only. Pistillate flowers are for the first time described for E. bokorensis. Glochidion geoffrayi (Phyllanthaceae) was considered endemic to southern Cambodia, and Lysimachia nutantiflora (Primulaceae) was only known from Guangxi, China. For each species, we provide analytical photographs, information on its habitat, phenology, distribution and studied specimens. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Gia Lai Province; Indochinese Peninsula; Kon Ha Nung Highland Biosphere Reserve; Southeast Asia

Authors: Bui, T.V.; Echizen, I.; Kuribayashi, M.; Kojima, T.; Nguyen, T.D.
Author full names: Bui, Thach V. (37760985000); Echizen, Isao (6602366829); Kuribayashi, Minoru (7005343250); Kojima, Tetsuya (35317993700); Nguyen, Thuc Dinh (55473698900)
Title: Group Testing with Blocks of Positives and Inhibitors
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, National University of Singapore, Singapore City, Singapore; Research Organization of Information and Systems National Institute of Informatics, Tokyo, Japan; Department of Information and Communication Engineering, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; National Institute of Technology, Japan, Hachioji, Japan; Faculty of Information Technology, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Faculty of Information Technology, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Bui, Thach V., Department of Computer Science, National University of Singapore, Singapore City, Singapore; Echizen, Isao, Research Organization of Information and Systems National Institute of Informatics, Tokyo, Japan, Department of Information and Communication Engineering, The University of Tokyo, Tokyo, Japan; Kuribayashi, Minoru, Okayama University, Okayama, Japan; Kojima, Tetsuya, National Institute of Technology, Japan, Hachioji, Japan; Nguyen, Thuc Dinh, Faculty of Information Technology, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Faculty of Information Technology, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: The main goal of group testing is to identify a small number of specific items among a large population of items. In this paper, we consider specific items as positives and inhibitors and non-specific items as negatives. In particular, we consider a novel model called group testing with blocks of positives and inhibitors. A test on a subset of items is positive if the subset contains at least one positive and does not contain any inhibitors, and it is negative otherwise. In this model, the input items are linearly ordered, and the positives and inhibitors are subsets of small blocks (at unknown locations) of consecutive items over that order. We also consider two specific instantiations of this model. The first instantiation is that model that contains a single block of consecutive items consisting of exactly known numbers of positives and inhibitors. The second instantiation is the model that contains a single block of consecutive items containing known numbers of positives and inhibitors. Our contribution is to propose efficient encoding and decoding schemes such that the numbers of tests used to identify only positives or both positives and inhibitors are less than the ones in the state-of-the-art schemes. Moreover, the decoding times mostly scale to the numbers of tests that are significantly smaller than the state-of-the-art ones, which scale to both the number of tests and the number of items. © 2023 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: combinatorics; inhibitors; non-adaptive group testing; sparse recovery; sub-linear algorithms

Title: GIS-Based Simulation for Landfill Site Selection in Mekong Delta: A Specific Application in Ben Tre Province
Affiliations: Department of Hydrogeology and Engineering Geology, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Faculty of Civil Engineering, Van Lang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Department of Fundamental Geology, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Fukui College, National Institute of Technology, Fukui College, Sabae, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Dinh Thanh, Department of Hydrogeology and Engineering Geology, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Truong, Minh Hoang, Faculty of Civil Engineering, Van Lang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ngo, Thi Phuong Uyen, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Department of Fundamental Geology, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Le, Anh Minh, Department of Hydrogeology and Engineering Geology, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Yamato, Yuya, Fukui College, National Institute of Technology, Fukui College, Sabae, Japan
Abstract: The aim of this research is to develop a GIS-based simulation for selecting the most suitable site of solid waste landfill which could help to minimize harmful impacts to the environment and society in the extreme sensitive and complex delta by an integration of geographic information system (GIS) and analysis hierarchy process (AHP) and nine criteria (distance from surface water; depth of ground water table; distance from residential area, land use, distance from main roads, geo-environmental and geotechnical characteristics, distance from historical and tourism sites, and distance from industrial zones). Different from most of the previous studies on the landfill site selection, geology-related criteria including soil types/lithology, soil permeability, and soil depth/soil thickness (soil-structure), which are called geo-environmental and geotechnical characteristics in this research, will be carefully considered, integrated, and evaluated. The AHP was employed to determine the weight of each criterion based on pair weight comparison and its matrix, while a land suitability index (LSI) score was calculated to determine the most suitable site. Moreover, the suitability map was also created which indicated very advantageous, advantageous, rather advantageous, and disadvantageous areas in the study area for landfill siting. Finally, the developed model could be used for supporting planners, managers, policy makers, and local government to make decisions on suitable and effective planning strategies for landfill site selection and could be applied anywhere and especially in other deltas around the world. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: analytic hierarchy process; location choice; model builder; planning support; relative weight

Authors: Do, T.-L.; Tran, M.-K.; Nguyen, H.H.; Tran, M.-T.
Author full names: Do, Trongle (57212828893); Tran, Mai Khiem (57208841121); Nguyen, Huy H. (55774055400); Tran, Minh Triet (35176729700)
Title: Potential Attacks of DeepFake on eKYC Systems and Remedy for eKYC with DeepFake Detection Using Two-Stream Network of Facial Appearance and Motion Features
Affiliations: University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Research Organization of Information and Systems National Institute of Informatics, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Do, Trongle, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tran, Mai Khiem, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Huy H., Research Organization of Information and Systems National Institute of Informatics, Tokyo, Japan; Tran, Minh Triet, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: eKYC, or electronic Know Your Customer, is an electronic or online customer identification allowing banks to completely identify customers online, simplifying paperwork or biometrics verification without having to meet face-to-face at the transaction office like traditional KYC. This new promising trend is becoming widely used in banks and various online services. Thus, eKYC can be a potential target for biometrics spoofing, including possible attacks by deepfake media, such as face swap or manipulation. In this paper, we introduce a potential attack of deepfake photos or videos on eKYC by swapping and manipulating faces between source and target faces. We then propose a novel method to detect fake videos of human faces using a two-stream network. We intend to utilize both the visual appearance and motion of a face in a sequence of pictures. We also propose to encode motion in an image sequence as an average photo which is called a motion-encoded image. Experiments on FaceForensics+ + show that using only a small number of frames in a video, our method can provide high accuracy in both frame-level and video-level prediction. With only 10 frames, our solution achieves the accuracy of 0.9326 and 0.9357 for the frame and video-level accuracy, respectively. If we use up to 50 frames per video, the accuracy of our method increases to 0.9371 and 0.9486 at the frame and video level. Finally, we propose to augment the security of current eKYC systems with deepfake detection. Our solution for deepfake detection can be a promising method to provide extra protection for eKYC solutions with face registration and authentication. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Deepfake detection; EKYC; Faceswap; Two-stream network

Authors: Pham, N.Q.; Ohtsuka, S.; Isobe, K.; Fukumoto, Y.
Author full names: Pham, N. Quang (57204521381); Ohtsuka, S. S. (35366838500); Isobe, Koichi (26641173800); Fukumoto, Yutaka (55598170400)
Title: Limit load space of rigid strip footing on cohesive-frictional soil subjected to eccentrically inclined loads
Affiliations: Faculty of Transportation Mechanical Engineering, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Division of Field Engineering for the Environment, Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Pham, N. Quang, Faculty of Transportation Mechanical Engineering, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Ohtsuka, S. S., Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Isobe, Koichi, Division of Field Engineering for the Environment, Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan; Fukumoto, Yutaka, Department of Civil & Environmental Engineering, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan
Abstract: In geotechnical engineering, the stability of strip footings under eccentrically inclined coupled loads is a major concern. The objective of this paper was to estimate the ultimate bearing capacity of a rigid strip footing, subjected to eccentrically inclined loads resting on cohesive-frictional soil, using the rigid plastic finite element method (RPFEM). In the numerical analysis, an interface element was introduced to properly evaluate the interaction between the footing base and the soil. The footing base was assumed to be rigid and rough, as it most often is in reality. Focus was placed on the effect of the soil properties (cohesive strength c, internal friction angle ϕ, and unit self-weight γ) and footing width B on the loading planes of the V-H-M limit load space (vertical load-horizontal load-moment) in order to consider the uniqueness of this limit load space. In particular, the effect of the two directions of the horizontal load, namely, positive and negative horizontal loads, on the V-H-M limit load space was clarified. The numerical results of the RPFEM showed that the negative horizontal load had a positive effect on supporting a higher bearing capacity than the positive horizontal load in the presence of a small eccentricity length. However, the results also showed a negligible effect on the bearing capacity for both directions of the horizontal load in the presence of a large eccentricity length. New equations were proposed to determine the V-H-M limit load space, predicted as functions of c/γB and ϕ, by taking into account the direction of the horizontal load. The applicability of the V-H-M limit load space was widely examined for several loading paths with different prescribed loads for V, H, and M. Consequently, the limit load space of the strip footing was clearly found to be unique for each value of c/γB and ϕ. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: C-ϕ soil; Eccentric loading; Inclined loading; Strip footing; Ultimate bearing capacity

Title: Unraveling the hierarchical genetic structure of tea green leafhopper, Matsumurasca onukii, in East Asia based on SSRs and SNPs
Affiliations: Entomological Museum, Northwest A&F University, Yangling, China; Jiujiang University, Jiujiang, China; Illinois Natural History Survey, Champaign, United States; College of Agriculture, Jiangxi Agricultural University, Nanchang, China; Mientrung Institute for Scientific Research, Vietnam National Museum of Nature, Hue, Viet Nam; Graduate School of Science and Technology, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; College of Agronomy, Xinyang Agriculture and Forestry University, Xinyang, China; Institute for Plant Protection, National Agriculture and Food Research Organization, NARO, Tsukuba, Japan

Abstract: Matsumurasca onukii (Matsuda, R. (1952). Oyo-Kontyu Tokyo, 8(1): 19–21), one of the dominant pests in major tea production areas in Asia, currently is known to occur in Japan, Vietnam, and China, and severely threatens tea production, quality, and international trade. To elucidate the population genetic structure of this species, 1633 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and 18 microsatellite markers (SSRs) were used to genotype samples from 27 sites representing 18 geographical populations distributed throughout the known range of the species in East Asia. Analyses of both SNPs and SSRs showed that M. onukii populations in Yunnan exhibit high-genetic differentiation and structure compared with the other populations. The Kagoshima (JJ) and Shizuoka (JS) populations from Japan were separated from populations from China by SNPs, but clustered with populations from Jinhua (JH), Yingde (YD), Guilin (GL), Fuzhou (FZ), Hainan (HQ), Leshan (CT), Chongqing (CY), and Zunyi (ZY) tea plantations in China and the Vietnamese Vinh Phuc (VN) population based on the SSR data. In contrast, CT, CY, ZY, and Shaanxi (SX) populations clustered together based on SNPs, but were separated by SSRs. Both marker datasets identified significant geographic differentiation among the 18 populations. Various environmental and anthropogenic factors, including geographical barriers to migration, human transport of hosts (Camellia sinesis [L.] O. Kuntze) and adaptation of M. onukii to various local climatic zones possibly account for the rapid spread of this pest in Asia. The results demonstrate that SNPs from high-throughput genotyping data can be used to reveal subtle genetic substructure at broad scales in r-strategist insects. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Matsumurasca onukii; reduced-representation genome sequencing; SNPs; SSRs; subtle genetic differentiation; tea pest

Title: Microbubbles improve removal of oil-in-water emulsions stabilized by humic acids
Affiliations: Faculty of Environmental Science, University of Sciences, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, The University of Kitakyushu, Kitakyushu, Japan; Division of Environmental Science and Engineering, Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Le, Tuan Van, Faculty of Environmental Science, University of Sciences, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Dang, Loc Thi Thanh, Faculty of Environmental Science, University of Sciences, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Yasui, Hidenari, Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, The University of Kitakyushu, Kitakyushu, Japan; IMAI, Tsuyoshi, Division of Environmental Science and Engineering, Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan
Abstract: This study examined the stability of fine oil-in-water (O/W) emulsions containing natural organic matter (500 mg·L–1 soybean oil and 25 mg·L–1 humic acid), named O/W-HA emulsions, formed by high-speed mixing. The calculated stability values from a 300-min stability test indicated that O/W-HA emulsions were more stable than O/W emulsions. Size distribution and Sauter mean diameter (D<inf>32</inf>) of oil droplets were calculated to evaluate the use of microbubbles (MB) in treating fine O/W-HA emulsions at different airflow rates, pH levels, and sodium chloride concentrations. At a prac-tical pressure (0.45 MPa), the designed column flotation system, featuring an F.BT-50 nozzle, produced a variety of gas bubbles to enhance separation. The application of MB in treating O/W-HA emulsion droplets (<15 μm, mean: 4.91 μm) and/or the addition of NaCl (30 mg·L–1) after 30 min of treatment increased the removal efficiency (from 60% to 82%) at pH 4.0. The results are meaningful for scale-up at treatment plants that produce oily wastewater because they indicate a high potential for the reduction and reuse of oil-floated products to improve treatment efficiency. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Emulsions; Flotation; Humic acid; Microbubbles; Oil-in-water; Wastewater treatment
Index Keywords: concentration (composition); emulsion; humic acid; organic matter; pH; wastewater treatment

Title: Development of electrochemical sensor based on polyalanine/CuCl-Gr/DWCNTs for highly sensitive detection of glyphosate
Affiliations: Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Department of Physics, Nha Trang University, Nha Trang, Viet Nam; Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Physics and Electronics, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tan Trao University, Tuyen Quang, Viet Nam; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Joining and Welding Research Institute, Ibaraki, Japan; Prokhorov General Physics Institute of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation

Abstract: In this study, a hybrid film based on copper chloride doped graphene/double-walled carbon nanotubes (CuCl-Gr/DWCNTs) was prepared for further application in detection of glyphosate (Gly) at low levels. Gr/DWCNTs film was first fabricated on copper foil and then modified with CuCl using thermal chemical vapor deposition (CVD) technique, before being transferred onto gold screen printed electrode (AuE). An ad-layer polyalanine (PolyA) was introduced on the top of CuCl-Gr/DWCNTs hybrid film by direct electro-deposition from alanine monomer in order to facilitate immobilization of enzyme molecules. The as-prepared PolyA/CuCl-Gr/DWCNT film was finally used for developing Gly electrochemical sensor based on inhibition of Gly towards urease enzyme. The developed Gly sensor showed a high sensitivity of 1383 (μA.ppb−1.cm−2) and a low detection limit (LOD) of 0.54 × 10−3 ppb in a wide concentration range of 10−3 ppb - 50 ppb. Moreover, the sensor was also applied to the detection of Gly in river water samples, with recoveries ranging from 112.8 % to 113.9 % (RSD: 1.54–2.03 %). The results suggested that the developed sensor with high sensitivity can be used for the detection of Gly in water sources. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: CuCl-doped Gr/DWCNTs; Electrochemical sensor; Glyphosate; PolyA

Title: Improving the efficiency of n-Si/PEDOT:PSS hybrid solar cells by incorporating AuNP-decorated graphene oxide as a nanoadditive for conductive polymers
Affiliations: Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology Institute of Materials Science, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Institute of Science and Technology, Thai Nguyen University of Sciences, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam; National Institute for Materials Science, Tsukuba, Japan

Abstract: A gold nanoparticle-decorated graphene oxide (GO-AuNP) hybrid material was prepared by using the chemical reduction method. The obtained results showed that the AuNPs of about of 15 nm are well bound on the surface of GO. The GO-AuNP hybrid material was used for transparent conductive film (TCF) and organic/inorganic hybrid solar cells. The TCF based on poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(styrene sulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS) containing GO-AuNPs was fabricated at room temperature. The obtained results show that the TCF containing 0.5 wt% GO-AuNPs has a high transmittance of 69.7% at 550 nm, a low sheet resistance of 50.5 Ω □−1 and a conductivity that increased to 3960 S cm−1, which is three times higher than those of the PEDOT:PSS and PEDOT:PSS/GO film. The power conversion efficiency (PCE) of the n-Si/PEDOT:PSS hybrid solar cell containing GO-AuNPs was 8.39% and is higher than pristine PEDOT:PSS (5.81%) and PEDOT:PSS/GO (7.58%). This is a result of the increased electrical conductivity and localized surface plasmon resonance of the PEDOT:PSS coating layer containing the GO-AuNP hybrid material. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Emergence of Different Replica Dirac Cones and Intra- and Intervalley Scatterings in Short-Wavelength Graphene Superlattices Modulated by an Atomic-Scale Sharp Potential
Affiliations: University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; High Performance Computing Laboratory, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Faculty of Physics, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Faculty of Natural Sciences, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Vu, Nam Hoang, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Le, Hieuvan, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Phan, Thang Bach, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Center for Innovative Materials and Architectures, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thoai, Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, High Performance Computing Laboratory, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Toan The, Faculty of Physics, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Hungminh, Faculty of Natural Sciences, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Minh Cao, Thi, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HUTECH, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: Here, we calculate the unfolded band structure of short-wavelength graphene superlattices modulated by the atomic-scale sharp potential of a semiconductor surface, using density functional theory. We show that in the case of the superlattice graphene Brillouin zone (SBZ) center folded into the primitive graphene Brillouin zone (GBZ) corner, the emergence of different replica Dirac cones and their scattering behaviors are driven by the substrate-induced potential or atomic-scale disorders as well as by the correlation between the rotation angle of the superlattice and the trigonal warping orientation of the Dirac cone because of the quantum interference associated with the scattering at the SBZ edge. In particular, a superlattice with a rotational angle of φ = 30° (G-N√3 × N√3-R30°, N > 1) facilitates intervalley scattering, whereas an unrotated superlattice (G-N3 × N3) is favorable to intravalley scattering. For a superlattice with a rotational angle in the range of 0 < φ < 30°, the intervalley and intravalley scatterings may be comparable to each other, leading to the emergence of mixed inequivalent replica cones at the SBZ center (or GBZ corner). Interestingly, such inequivalent replica cones facilitate a stronger intervalley scattering at the GBZ corner, compared to the G-N√3 × N√3-R30° and G-N3 × N3 superlattices, thus opening a larger energy gap at the primitive Dirac point. In addition to the inversion symmetry breaking in graphene, we show that intervalley scattering can also generate an energy gap at the secondary Dirac point. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Atoms; Density functional theory; Energy gap; A: semiconductors; Atomic scale; Brillouin zones; Dirac cones; Dirac point; Graphene superlattices; Intervalley scattering; Rotational angle; Semi-conductor surfaces; Short wavelengths; Graphene

Authors: Duong, N.T.; Tran, K.Q.; Satomi, T.; Takahashi, H.

Title: Effects of agricultural by-product on mechanical properties of cemented waste soil
Affiliations: Faculty of Civil Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Faculty of Civil Engineering, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Duong, Thanh Nga, Faculty of Civil Engineering, Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology - HCMUT, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Tran, Khiem Quang, Faculty of Civil Engineering, Ton-Duc-Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Satomi, Tomoaki, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Takahashi, Hiroshi, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: Waste soil produced from construction sites currently emerges as a big problem to environment. These soils cannot be reused directly cause of its weakness in strength properties. Hence, this study focuses on improving mechanical properties of waste soil by using cement and corn husk fiber. The environment has also benefited from using corn husk fiber since corn husk is agricultural by-product. In order to evaluate the impact of corn husk fiber and cement on mechanical characteristics of waste soil, a series of laboratory experiments containing tension and compression test is carried out. In addition, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) test is conducted to investigate interaction between fibers and soil-cement matrix. Fiber content from 0 to 1% by dry soil mass and corn husk lengths of 10 and 30 mm are used in this research. The results present that strength properties of cemented soil are enhanced when fiber is added. The most improvements corresponding to compressive strength, splitting tensile strength, and direct tensile strength are 30.6%, 206.1%, and 27.9%, respectively. A strong interaction between fibers and soil-cement matrix observed from SEM results in the improvement of strength properties of cemented soil. Fiber inclusion contributes to the more ductile and durable behavior under loading. Fiber length and fiber content have a remarkable effect on the cemented soil behavior. The increase in fiber length and content leads to the increase in residual stress and the decrease in loss of post-peak stress. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Compressive strength; Corn husk fiber; Direct tensile strength; Fiber-cement-stabilized soil; Soil improvement

Authors: Tran, T.P.A.; Katsumi, T.; Tran, T.N.
Author full names: Tran, Thi Phuong An (57194383537); Katsumi, Takeshi (57219346257); Tran, T. N. (58280610300)
Title: Gellan Gum for Strengthening Bentonite-Sand Slurry
Affiliations: Department of Hydrogeological and Geotechnical Engineering, University of Sciences, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Graduate School of Global Environmental Studies, Kyoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Thi Phuong An, Department of Hydrogeological and Geotechnical Engineering, University of Sciences, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Katsumi, Takeshi, Graduate School of Global Environmental Studies, Kyoto, Japan; Tran, T. N., Department of Hydrogeological and Geotechnical Engineering, University of Sciences, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam
Abstract: The strengthening ability associated with adding a gellan gum as an additive to bentonite slurry for use in coating soil surfaces was studied. Bentonite powder was mixed with hot gellan gum hydrogel (i.e., at 200 °C) to different gellan gum concentrations (i.e., 0, 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7% of the mass of distilled water). A series of unconfined compressive strength tests were conducted on gellan gum-bentonite mixtures subjected to various thermal curing conditions. The shrinkage behavior was observed during the thermal curing process. The research also studied the sand size particle effect on the strength and volume change of the dried gellan gum-modified bentonite. The test results showed the soil strengthening effect of adding gellan gum to bentonite slurry which was then added it to bentonite/silica sand mixtures. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Nguyen, T.D.; Nguyen-Dang, D.N.; Le-Viet, T.; Fujita, G.
Author full names: Nguyen, Duc Tuyen (58279068400); Nguyen-Dang, Duong (57885564700); Le-Viet, Thinh (57221553909); Fujita, Goro (36186886000)
Title: Continuous Reconfiguration Framework for Photovoltaic Array under Variable Partial Shading Conditions: Heuristic-Based Algorithms with Optimizing Switching Operation
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Duc Tuyen, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Nguyen-Dang, Duong, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le-Viet, Thinh, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Fujita, Goro, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The operation of the photovoltaic (PV) system under partial shading conditions (PSC) is complicated since the output characteristic of the PV system is profoundly affected by the heterogeneous irradiance of PSC. This paper proposes a dynamic reconfiguration framework to tackle PSC in the PV array. Continuous operation of the dynamic PV array reconfiguration under cloud-induced partial shading is considered by developing an emulator of the moving cloud. In addition, the Particle Swarm Optimization and Rao algorithms are improved to obtain the optimal PV array configuration under PSC. The operation of switching is enhanced by simultaneously considering the total switching times and the operation of highly active switches. The simulation results on the (Formula presented.) PV array demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed framework in terms of reducing the number of local maximum power points on the power-voltage characteristic, enhancing power output, and relieving stress on the switching operation of the PV array under different PSC. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: dynamic PV array reconfiguration; moving cloud; PSO algorithm; Rao algorithm; switching optimization; time lag
Index Keywords: Dynamic models; Heuristic algorithms; Particle swarm optimization (PSO); Condition; Dynamic photovoltaic array reconfiguration; Moving cloud; Partial shading; Photovoltaic arrays; PSO algorithms; Rao algorithm; Switching operations; Switching optimization; Time lag; Switching

Authors: Nguyen, T.D.; Le-Viet, T.; Nguyen-Dang, D.N.; Dao-Quang, T.; Bui, M.
Author full names: Nguyen, Duc Tuyen (58279068400); Le-Viet, Thinh (57221553909); Nguyen-Dang, Duong (57885564700); Dao-Quang, Tung (57886496300); Bui, Quang Minh (57423693300)
Title: Photovoltaic Array Reconfiguration under Partial Shading Conditions Based on Short-Circuit Current Estimated by Convolutional Neural Network
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nguyen, Duc Tuyen, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Le-Viet, Thinh, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen-Dang, Duong, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dao-Quang, Tung, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Bui, Quang Minh, Department of Electrical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: Partial shading conditions (PSC) have negative effects on the operation of photovoltaic (PV) systems. In this paper, a PV array reconfiguration method is developed to minimize power losses of PV arrays under partial shading conditions. The proposed reconfiguration method is based on equalizing the reduction of the short-circuit current of the PV modules in the PV array. Eight state-of-the-art Convolutional Neural Network models are employed to estimate the effect of shading on the short-circuit current of a PV module. These models include LeNet-5, AlexNet, VGG 11, VGG 19, Inception V3, ResNet 18, ResNet 34, and ResNet 50. Among eight models, the VGG 19 achieves the best accuracy on 1842 sample images. Therefore, this model is used to estimate the ratio of the actual short-circuit current and the estimated short-circuit current in four studied shading scenarios. This ratio decides the switching rule between PV modules throughout the PV array under PSC. A (Formula presented.) experimental PV array shows that the proposed reconfiguration method improves the output power from 5.81% to 25.19% in four shading patterns. Accordingly, the power losses are reduced from 1.32% to 13.75%. The power improvement and the reduction of power losses of the proposed dynamic PV array reconfiguration system under four case studies demonstrates its effectiveness in addressing the effects of PSC on the PV array. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Convolutional Neural Network; dynamic photovoltaic array reconfiguration; experimental analysis; image processing; partial shading conditions

Authors: Truong, T.T.C.; Kobayashi, T.; van Tran, L.
Author full names: Truong, Trang Cam (57211073515); Kobayashi, Takaomi (55724278400); van Tran, Lam (57404976000)
Title: Preparation, characterization, and application of hydrogel derived from chitin with lithium chloride for growth and development of rosemary plants
Affiliations: Faculty of Environmental Science, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Department of Science of Technology Innovation, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; Research and Development Center for Radiation Technology, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Truong, Trang Cam, Faculty of Environmental Science, University of Science, Viet Nam National University Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Kobayashi, Takaomi, Department of Science of Technology Innovation, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan; van Tran, Lam, Research and Development Center for Radiation Technology, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: In this study, the N,N-dimethyl acetamide (DMAc) solution with different lithium chloride concentrations of 3 wt%, 5 wt%, and 7 wt% by phase inversion in ethanol vapor to produce chitin hydrogels for plant growth. The chitin hydrogel prepared with a higher concentration of lithium chloride showed improvements in elastic and mechanical properties. The tensile strength was enhanced from 275.8 to 434 kPa for the chitin hydrogel with 3% and 7% of LiCl. While the reduction in water content suggested forming a denser hydrogel structure at higher LiCl concentrations; the water contact angle (WCA) value indicated that chitin-derived hydrogels are hydrophilic. Moreover, the bio-degradation experiment indicated the degradable percent of the chitin hydrogel placed in 10 mg/L of aqueous lysozyme solutions at 37°C increases during 7 to 28 days from 4.72 wt% to 5.45 wt%. The obtained hydrogel was suitable for the growth and development on rosemary plants. The condition CE15 with the hydrogel of 85 wt% chitin-derived hydrogel and 15 wt% cellulose as best medium planting with the largest effect on the height, the crown's diameters and the number of level-one branches of the rosemary plants. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: bio-degradation; chitin hydrogel; phase inversion; rosemary

Authors: Giang, H.T.N.; Duy, D.T.T.; Hieu, L.T.M.; Vuong, N.L.; Ngoc, N.T.T.; Phuong, M.T.; Huy, N.T.
Author full names: Giang, Hoang Thi Nam (57201741396); Duy, Do Thi Thuy (57786849700); Hieu, Le Tho Minh (57786257200); Vuong, Nguyen Lam (57191268954); Ngoc, Nguyen Thi Tu (57788346600); Phuong, Mai Thi (57864602800); Huy, Nguyen Tien (57209480434)
Title: Factors associated with the very high caesarean section rate in urban areas of Vietnam
Affiliations: School of Medicine and Pharmacy, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; University of Medicine and Pharmacy at HCMC, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Thai Nguyen University, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam; Hung Vuong Hospital, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; School of Tropical Medicine and Global Health, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Giang, Hoang Thi Nam, School of Medicine and Pharmacy, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Duy, Do Thi Thuy, School of Medicine and Pharmacy, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Hieu, Le Tho Minh, School of Medicine and Pharmacy, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Vuong, Nguyen Lam, University of Medicine and Pharmacy at HCMC, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Ngoc, Nguyen Thi Tu, Thai Nguyen University, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam; Phuong, Mai Thi, Hung Vuong Hospital, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Huy, Nguyen Tien, School of Tropical Medicine and Global Health, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, Japan
Abstract: Background Caesarean section and associated factors require detailed investigation globally. This study aims to determine the rate and associated factors of caesarean deliveries in urban areas of Vietnam. Methods A cross-sectional study using questionnaire answered by women who had infants aged under 30 months was conducted from March to May 2021. Data were collected in 18 commune health centres in two cities during the day of routine immunization. Multivariable logistic regression was performed to assess factors associated with caesarean section. Results The overall caesarean section rate was 49.6%. The caesarean section rate in private hospitals (57.8%) were significantly higher than in public hospitals (49.1%). Caesarean section rate in first-time mothers (47.1%) were as high as this rate among mothers who had given birth before (50.6%). Factors associated with higher rate of caesarean section include increasing in women’s age, pre-pregnancy body mass index, gestational weight gain, and infant’s birth weight; first-time mothers; mothers living in urban areas; and mothers giving birth in private hospitals. Conclusions This study revealed a high rate of caesarean deliveries in urban areas of Vietnam. Comprehensive investigations of both medical and non-medical reasons for caesarean deliveries in Vietnam are urgent needs to shape the prioritized interventions. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Title: Selective recovery of thorium and uranium from leach solutions of rare earth concentrates in continuous solvent extraction mode with primary amine N1923
Affiliations: Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ministry of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan; Quang Binh University, Quang Binh, Viet Nam; Institute of Fundamental and Applied Sciences, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Resources Utilization Division, Korea Institute of Geoscience and Mineral Resources, Daejeon, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Hung, Nguyentrong, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thuan, Le Ba, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thanh, Tran Chi, Ministry of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Thuy, Nguyen Thanh, Vietnam Atomic Energy Institute, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Tra, Doan Thi Thu, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; do van, Khoai, Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan; Watanabe, Masayuki, Japan Atomic Energy Agency, Kashiwa, Japan; Minh, Pham Quang, Ministry of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Than, Hoang Sy, Ministry of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vuong, Nguyen Duc, Quang Binh University, Quang Binh, Viet Nam; Van-Phuc, Dinh, Institute of Fundamental and Applied Sciences, Duy Tan University, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Lee, Jinyoung, Resources Utilization Division, Korea Institute of Geoscience and Mineral Resources, Daejeon, South Korea; Jeon, Jong Hyuk, Resources Utilization Division, Korea Institute of Geoscience and Mineral Resources, Daejeon, South Korea; Jyothi, Rajesh Kumar, Resources Utilization Division, Korea Institute of Geoscience and Mineral Resources, Daejeon, South Korea
Abstract: A continuous counter-current extraction for the selective recovery of thorium (Th) and uranium (U) from the Yen Phu (Vietnam) rare earth concentrate leach solutions was systematically studied. The primary amine N1923 was used as an extractant which was prepared in the isoparaffin IP-2028 diluent. Thorium and uranium were selectively recovered in a hydrometallurgical circuit established by continuous mixer-settler extraction, scrubbing, and back-extraction at the laboratory scale. The desired purity of Th and U can be achieved by managing the volume ratio of organic to aqueous phase (O/A ratio) in the corresponding steps. Highly pure Th and U were recovered from the pregnant back-extraction liquor and the raffinate, respectively, which have satisfactory properties for further processing of the subsequent nuclear materials. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Author full names: Tran, Lieu Thi (58253022400); Kieu, Tien Cao (57751487600); Bui, Hien Minh (57220524734); Nguyen, Trong Nghia (59053809200); Nguyen, Thi Thu Thuy (57210155966); Nguyen-Tien, Dat (57214528587); Nguyen, Trung Quang (56033836800); Nguyen, Huong Thi Thu (59662807600); Le, Tuyen Huu (57216956013); Takahashi, Shin (7407713609); Minh, Tu Binh (7004322947); Hoang, Anhquoc (56789775300)
Title: Polybrominated diphenyl ethers in indoor dusts from industrial factories, offices, and houses in northern Vietnam: Contamination characteristics and human exposure
Affiliations: Vietnam National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Faculty of Chemical Technology and Environment, Hung Yen University of Technology and Education, Khoai Chau, Viet Nam; Faculty of Chemistry, Thai Nguyen University of Sciences, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam; Center for Research and Technology Transfer, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Ehime University, Matsuyama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Lieu Thi, Vietnam National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Kieu, Tien Cao, Vietnam National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Bui, Hien Minh, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Trong Nghia, Faculty of Chemical Technology and Environment, Hung Yen University of Technology and Education, Khoai Chau, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Thi Thu Thuy, Faculty of Chemistry, Thai Nguyen University of Sciences, Thai Nguyen, Viet Nam; Nguyen-Tien, Dat, Center for Research and Technology Transfer, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Trung Quang, Center for Research and Technology Transfer, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Huong Thi Thu, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Le, Tuyen Huu, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Takahashi, Shin, Ehime University, Matsuyama, Japan; Minh, Tu Binh, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Hoang, Anhquoc, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Ehime University, Matsuyama, Japan
Abstract: Information about the occurrence of polybrominated diphenyl ethers (PBDEs) in indoor dusts from various industrial sectors in Southeast Asia is still scarce. In this study, concentrations and congener-specific profiles of PBDEs were determined in indoor dusts from industrial factories, offices, and houses in northern Vietnam. Levels of Σ8PBDEs were higher in the office dusts (median 270; range 230–300 ng/g) and factory dusts (170; 89–510 ng/g) than in the house dusts (61; 25–140 ng/g). BDE-209 was the most dominant congener, accounting for 27–98% (average 62%) of Σ8PBDEs, suggesting the abundance of products treated with deca-BDE mixtures. Residential, commercial, and industrial activities in the studied locations of this survey were not significant sources of PBDEs as compared to those of informal waste processing activities in Vietnam. Relatively low PBDE concentrations detected in our dust samples partially reflect effectiveness of the global PBDE phase-out. Human exposure and health risk associated with dust-bound PBDEs were estimated, indicating acceptable levels of risk (i.e., neurobehavioral effects). The contributions of workplace dusts in total daily intake doses of PBDEs via dust ingestion were more important for local workers in informal recycling areas than factory workers and general population, raising the need of appropriate labor protection measures. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Bui, H.Q.; Kawabata, M.; van Nguyen, C.
Author full names: Bui, Quang Hieu (57219845287); Kawabata, Masaya (57200617582); van Nguyen, Chinh (56540678500)
Title: A combination of genetic algorithm and dynamic relaxation method for practical form-finding of tensegrity structures
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Graduate School of Urban Innovation, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Bui, Quang Hieu, Department of Civil Engineering, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam; Kawabata, Masaya, Graduate School of Urban Innovation, Yokohama National University, Yokohama, Japan; van Nguyen, Chinh, Department of Civil Engineering, University of Danang, Da Nang, Viet Nam
Abstract: A combination of Genetic algorithm (GA) and Dynamic Relaxation (DR) method is presented for practical form-finding of tensegrity structures. Several approaches of dynamic relaxation method are reviewed for form-finding of tensegrity structures, and the negative points of DR method where the final form is sensitive to the initial form and cannot satisfy the geometrical constraint conditions are illustrated. The genetic algorithm is then proposed to obtain the initial configuration for DR method for finding the final shapes satisfying all constraint conditions. Several types of tensegrity structures are performed to point out the efficiency of proposed combination method. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: dynamic relaxation method; Genetic algorithm; tensegrity arch; tensegrity tower; truncated regular polyhedron

Authors: Tran, X.T.; Pham, A.H.; Vuong, V.; Vu, T.D.

Title: Stress and Distortion of 100Cr6 Steel after Quenching in Aqueous 4% Polyvinylpyrrolidone Solution
Source title: Journal of Materials Engineering and Performance
Affiliations: School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Department of Physics and Materials Science, Shimane University, Matsue, Japan; School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Tran, Xuan Thi, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Pham, Anh Hoang, Department of Physics and Materials Science, Shimane University, Matsue, Japan; Vuong, Hoang Van, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Vu, Toai Dinh, School of Mechanical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: The stress and distortion that remain in steel products after quenching are harmful and undesirable. Therefore, a selected quenching medium should have a cooling rate equal to or greater than the critical cooling rate of the steel to achieve high hardness values, but the cooling rate should not be too large in order to minimize stress and distortion on the specimen. This paper studied the hardness, stress and distortion of C-ring samples quenched in 4% polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP)-K60 solution and oil using simulated and experimental measurements. The results show that the maximum cooling rates (CR<inf>max</inf>) of oil and 4% PVP-K60 quenchants are both higher than the critical cooling rate of steel. The CR<inf>max</inf> of the 4% PVP-K60 solution is greater than that of the oil, and the cooling rate of the 4% PVP-K60 solution at 300 °C (CR<inf>300</inf>) is smaller than that of the oil. The greater the CR<inf>300</inf> is, the greater the hardness, stress and distortion are. Thus, the hardness, stress and distortion values of the quenched sample depend less on CR<inf>max</inf> and more on CR<inf>300.</inf> The research results also showed that a solution of 4% PVP-K60 could replace oil in the quenching of 100Cr6 steel. Simulated and experimental results of the hardness, stress and distortion of C-ring samples reflected the same rule. The errors between the simulation and experiment using the program and the computational conditions of distortion are approximately 20%. The numerical simulation method is entirely usable to predict the hardness, stress and distortion of a sample during the quenching process. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: 100Cr6; distortion; PVP; quenching; stress
Index Keywords: Cooling; Hardness; Numerical methods; 100cr6; Cooling rates; Critical cooling rate; Hardness values; High hardness; Maximum cooling; Polyvinylpyrrolidones; Quenchants; Quenching media; Steel products; Quenching

Title: Preparation and properties of colloidal silica-filled natural rubber grafted with poly(methyl methacrylate)
Affiliations: School of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Malaysian Rubber Board, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia; Department of Materials Science and Technology, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Thuong, Nghiem Thi, School of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dao van, Huong, School of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Cao, Ha H., School of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nguyen Thi Ha, Hanh, School of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Nurul Hayati, Yusof, Malaysian Rubber Board, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia; Kawahara, Seiichi, Department of Materials Science and Technology, Nagaoka University of Technology, Nagaoka, Japan
Abstract: Colloidal silica-filled deproteinized natural rubber (DPNR) grafted with poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) (DPNR-graft-PMMA/silica) was prepared and characterized. DPNR-graft-PMMA/silica was prepared by graft copolymerization of NR latex with MMA and tert-butyl hydroperoxide/tetraethylenepentamine as initiators, followed by the addition of silica precursor, i.e., vinyltriethoxysilane (VTES). Various amounts of colloidal silica were introduced by varying VTES concentrations accordingly. The resulting DPNR-graft-PMMA/silica sample was analyzed through Fourier transformed infrared and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. PMMA was successfully grafted on NR particles, and colloidal silica particles productively generated in DPNR-graft-PMMA latex. Properties of DPNR-graft-PMMA/silica, i.e., tensile strength and hardness, were significantly improved than those of DPNR. Low water contact angles of DPNR-graft-PMMA and DPNR-graft-PMMA/silica indicated the polar characteristic of colloidal silica and PMMA particles, enhancing the compatibility of those components in DPNR-graft-PMMA/silica. © 2025 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: Le, P.-A.; Le, V.-Q.; Tran, T.L.; Nguyen, N.T.; Phung, T.V.B.; Dinh, V.A.
Author full names: Le, Phuoc –.Anh (57211802056); Le, Van Qui (57217604418); Tran, Thien Lan (57215727981); Nguyen, Trong Nghia (56088215400); Phung, Thi Viet Bac (25422238000); Dinh, Van An (6603847411)
Title: Two-Dimensional NH4V3O8Nanoflakes as Efficient Energy Conversion and Storage Materials for the Hydrogen Evolution Reaction and Supercapacitors
Affiliations: Institute of Sustainability Science, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Faculty of Textile Science and Technology, Shinshu University, Matsumoto, Japan; Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Department of Physics, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; School of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Department of Precision Engineering, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Le, Phuoc –.Anh, Institute of Sustainability Science, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Faculty of Textile Science and Technology, Shinshu University, Matsumoto, Japan; Le, Van Qui, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, National Yang Ming Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Tran, Thien Lan, Institute of Sustainability Science, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam, Department of Physics, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Nguyen, Trong Nghia, School of Chemical Engineering, Hanoi University of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Phung, Thi Viet Bac, Institute of Sustainability Science, Vietnam National University, Hanoi, Hanoi, Viet Nam; Dinh, Van An, Department of Precision Engineering, The University of Osaka, Suita, Japan
Abstract: Herein, for the first time, we present two-dimensional (2D) NH<inf>4</inf>V<inf>3</inf>O<inf>8</inf>nanoflakes as an excellent material for both energy conversion of the hydrogen evolution reaction and storage of supercapacitors by a simple and fast two-step synthesis, which exhibit a completely sheet-like morphology, high crystallinity, good specific surface area, and also stability, as determined by thermogravimetric analysis. The 2D-NH<inf>4</inf>V<inf>3</inf>O<inf>8</inf>flakes show an acceptable hydrogen evolution performance in 0.5 M H<inf>2</inf>SO<inf>4</inf>on a glassy carbon electrode (GCE) coated with 2D-NH<inf>4</inf>V<inf>3</inf>O<inf>8</inf>, which results in a low overpotential of 314 mV at -10 mA cm-2with an excellent Tafel slope as low as 90 mV dec-1. So far, with the main focus on energy storage, 2D-NH<inf>4</inf>V<inf>3</inf>O<inf>8</inf>nanoflakes were found to be ideal for supercapacitor electrodes. The NH<inf>4</inf>V<inf>3</inf>O<inf>8</inf>working electrode in 1 M Na<inf>2</inf>SO<inf>4</inf>shows an excellent electrochemical capability of 274 F g-1at 0.5 A g-1for a maximum energy density of 38 W h kg-1at a power density as high as 250 W kg-1. Moreover, the crystal structure of 2D-NH<inf>4</inf>V<inf>3</inf>O<inf>8</inf>is demonstrated by density functional theory (DFT) computational simulation using three functionals, GGA, GGA + U, and HSE06. The simple preparation, low cost, and abundance of the NH<inf>4</inf>V<inf>3</inf>O<inf>8</inf>material provide a promising candidate for not only energy conversion but also energy-storage applications. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

(57223244808); Furusho, Hirotoshi (57219408049); Miyata, Makoto (7202009630); Shimonaka, Tomomi (7801657651); Bao Chau, Nguyen Ngoc (57820149300); Vinh, Nguyen Phuong (57223887039); Nghia, Nguyen Anh (24376898400); Mohammed, Tareg Omer (57223898983); Ichikawa, Takehiko (7402281223); Kodera, Noriyuki (6603242972); Konno, Hiroki (7201803403); Fukuma, Takeshi (7006634114); Nguyen, Quoc Bao (23489795700)
Title: Unraveling the Host-Selective Toxic Interaction of Cassiicolin with Lipid Membranes and Its Cytotoxicity
Affiliations: Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan; Research Institute for Biotechnology and Environment, Nong Lam University, Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Department of Biology, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Faculty of Biotechnology, Đại học Mở Thành phố Hồ Chí Minh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Rubber Research Institute of Vietnam, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Department of Biological Sciences, Nong Lam University, Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: Ngo, Kienxuan, Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan; Nguyen, Phuong Doan N., Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan, Research Institute for Biotechnology and Environment, Nong Lam University, Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Furusho, Hirotoshi, Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan; Miyata, Makoto, Department of Biology, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Shimonaka, Tomomi, Department of Biology, Osaka Metropolitan University, Osaka, Japan; Bao Chau, Nguyen Ngoc, Faculty of Biotechnology, Đại học Mở Thành phố Hồ Chí Minh, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Vinh, Nguyen Phuong, Rubber Research Institute of Vietnam, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Nghia, Nguyen Anh, Rubber Research Institute of Vietnam, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam; Mohammed, Tareg Omer, Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan; Ichikawa, Takehiko, Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan; Kodera, Noriyuki, Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan; Konno, Hiroki, Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan; Fukuma, Takeshi, Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Japan; Nguyen, Quoc Bao, Research Institute for Biotechnology and Environment, Nong Lam University, Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam, Department of Biological Sciences, Nong Lam University, Ho Chi Minh City, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam
Abstract: Cassiicolin (Cas), a toxin produced by Corynespora cassiicola, is responsible for Corynespora leaf fall disease in susceptible rubber trees. Currently, the molecular mechanisms of the cytotoxicity of Cas and its host selectivity have not been fully elucidated. Here, we analyzed the binding of Cas1 and Cas2 to membranes consisting of different plant lipids and their membrane disruption activities. Using high-speed atomic force microscopy and confocal microscopy, we reveal that the binding and disruption activities of Cas1 and Cas2 on lipid membranes are strongly dependent on the specific plant lipids. The negative phospholipids, glycerolipids, and sterols are more sensitive to membrane damage caused by Cas1 and Cas2 than neutral phospholipids and betaine lipids. Mature Cas1 and Cas2 play an essential role in causing membrane disruption. Cytotoxicity tests on rubber leaves of Rubber Research Institute of Vietnam (RRIV) 1, RRIV 4, and Prang Besar (PB) 255 clones suggest that the toxins cause necrosis of rubber leaves, except for the strong resistance of PB 255 against Cas2. Cryogenic scanning electron microscopy analyses of necrotic leaf tissues treated with Cas1 confirm that cytoplasmic membranes are vulnerable to the toxin. Thus, the host selectivity of Cas toxin is attained by the lipid-dependent binding activity of Cas to the membrane, and the cytotoxicity of Cas arises from its ability to form biofilm-like structures and to disrupt specific membranes. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

Authors: An, T.T.P.; Thanh Nhan, T.T.; Nhan, N.T.T.; Thien, D.Q.; Matsuda, H.; Pham, P.
Author full names: An, Tran Thi Phuong (57451954800); Thanh Nhan, Tran (55389173300); Nhan, Nguyen Thi Thanh (57369622200); Thien, Do Quang (56625865400); Matsuda, Hiroshi (35374097800); Pham, Tien V. (57210204837)
Title: Pore water pressure responses of saturated sand and clay under undrained cyclic shearing
Affiliations: University of Sciences, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan; Institute of Geological Sciences, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Authors with affiliations: An, Tran Thi Phuong, University of Sciences, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Thanh Nhan, Tran, University of Sciences, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Nhan, Nguyen Thi Thanh, University of Sciences, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Thien, Do Quang, University of Sciences, Hue University, Hue, Viet Nam; Matsuda, Hiroshi, Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan; Pham, Tien V., Institute of Geological Sciences, Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology, Hanoi, Viet Nam
Abstract: In this study, changes in the pore water pressure were observed for saturated specimens of a loose fined-grain sand (Nam O sand) and a soft silty clay (Hue clay) subjected to undrained cyclic shearing with different testing conditions. The cyclic shear tests were run for relatively wide range of shear strain amplitude (γ = 0.05%-2%), different cycle numbers (n = 10, 50, 150 and 200) and various shear directions (uni-direction and two-direction with phase difference of θ = 0°, 45° and 90°). It is indicated from the experimental results that under the same cyclic shearing condition, the pore water pressure accumulation in Hue clay is at a slower rate, suggesting a higher cyclic shear resistance of Hue clay than that of Nam O sand. Liquefaction is reached easily in nominally 50% relative density specimens of Nam O sand when γ ≥ 0.4%, meanwhile soft specimen of Hue clay is not liquefied regardless of the cyclic shearing conditions used in this study. The threshold number of cycles for the pore water pressure generation generally decreases with γ meanwhile, the threshold cumulative shear strain for such a property mostly approaches 0.1%. In addition, by using this new strain path parameter, it becomes more advantageous when evaluating the pore water pressure accumulation in Nam O sand and Hue clay subjected to undrained uni-directional and two-directional cyclic shears. © 2022 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Cyclic shear; effective stress; Hue clay; Nam O sand; pore water pressure
